First let's go back to your medical history a little bit and then we will continue with the result. Patient: Sure.

So, you first came to our Pulmonary Clinic, and you were suffering with dyspnea even on minimal exertion. At that time, we evaluated you and we realized that there was some evidence of irregular sleep and daytime fatigue. At that time you also complained of nighttime choking episodes which got less intense over the past many months.
That's right. I was then scheduled for the overnight sleep study to be evaluated for interruptions in my sleep and here we are today to discuss results.
Sure. But first tell me, how is your sleeping routine like?
It is consistent. I go to bed anytime between nine to ten at night and wake up in the morning around five to six.
Are you able to sleep as soon as you go to bed?

No, it's hard for me to start that sleeping process and then I'm awake in like every one or two hours throughout the night. I keep on tossing and turning throughout the night. I always find my sheets out of order when I wake up.
How would you compare your sleep here in the lab and at your home?
I would say I slept better in the laboratory than I do at home.
How do you feel when you wake up in the morning?
Honestly, I feel tired. Sometimes I also have this dull headache.
Do you snore?
I don't know for myself, but yeah, my daughter was teasing me another day that I was snoring and was talking in my sleep.
Did you ever feel that you have difficulty breathing while you are asleep?
No. But I used to cough a lot in the middle of the night.
You said you used to, so it is not anymore?
Yeah, I haven't been coughing for the last few weeks.
How's your daily routine? Do you nap in the daytime?
I spent a lot of time reading and watching T V. Sometimes I doze off while doing that. Not regular, but I do take nap sometimes in between two to three in afternoon and also in the evening hours.
Do you smoke?
Oh yes, I take around one to two packs of cigarettes each day mainly after dinner.
Have you noticed any change in your weight?
My weight always keeps fluctuating. I remember I was at my maximum weight of two hundred and sixty pounds around one year ago.
If that was your maximum how is your weight now?
Now it is down by approximately thirty pounds.
So, for your health care, you are coming here in the outpatient psychiatry and also going to your maintenance clinic, right?
Yes, that's right.
Your current medications include Methadone, Trazodone, and Seroquel.
That sounds right.

conversations.context: GERD, hypertension times 20 years, arthritis, Parkinson's, TIA, chronic atrial fibrillation, on Coumadin three years.

dialogue.message: So, I see you were diagnosed with an acid reflux problem and high blood pressure twenty years back?
Yes.
And then you also have arthritis and Parkinson's.
Yes, both.
Also, you had a brain stroke?
Yes, mini stroke!
Ah, yes. We also call it as T I A.
Okay.
And currently are you on any medications?
Just Coumadin, for my chronic A Fib. I have been on it three years.
Yeah, atrial fibrillation.
Yes.

conversations.context: The patient is 13-year-old male with persistent left knee pain.  He was initially seen at Sierra Pacific Orthopedic Group where an MRI demonstrated unstable OCD lesion of the left knee.  The patient presented here for a second opinion.  Surgery was recommended grossly due to the instability of the fragment.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion extremity, failure to relieve pain or restore the articular cartilage, possible need for other surgical procedures, and possible early arthritis.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Good afternoon, young man.
Good afternoon, doctor.
How old are you, sir?
I'm thirteen.
So, what brings you in today?
Guest_family: Well, at first, we went to Sierra Pacific Orthopedic Group, and he had an M R I that showed, um, O C D in the left knee.
Yes, I see that from the report.
Guest_family: So, we're here for a second opinion on that.
Yes, we should do surgery on this knee. There's gross instability of the fragment, and we don't want that get worse.
Guest_family: Okay, that's about what we've heard so far. What are the risks of infection of the procedure?

It's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection. Other risks include bleeding, changes in sensation of the limb, changes in motion, failure to relieve pain or restore the articular cartilage, the possible need for another procedure, and possible early arthritis. I would not worry, though. These things are rare.
Guest_family: Okay, will he be asleep the entire time?
Yes, he won't feel a thing.
Guest_family: Okay, my husband agrees. We want to do the surgery.

conversations.context: Significant for her being without a companion at this point.  She was born in Munich, Germany.  She immigrated to of America in 1957 after her family had to move to Eastern Germany, which was under Russian occupation at that time.  She is divorced.  She used to work as a secretary and later worked as a clerical worker at IBM.  She stopped working more than 20 years ago due to complications from her mesothelioma.  She denies any significant tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs.  She is bilingual speaking, German and English.  She has known English from before her teens.  She has the equivalent of a high school education in Germany.  She has one brother and one sister, both of whom are healthy and she does not spend much time communicating with them.  She has one son who lives in Santa Cruz.  He has grandchildren.  She is trying to contact with her grandchildren.

dialogue.message: You know doctor, I was born in Munich, Germany.
Wow, I cannot tell, you speak English so well, no German accent.
Yeah, I always knew how to speak English even before I was a teen. So, when I moved to America I did not have any language problem.
Okay and did you move with your family?
No, my family moved to the eastern side of the Germany which was occupied by Russia at that time, but I decided to move to America in nineteen fifty seven.
I had a high school degree from Germany, and I could speak German and English fluently.

As soon as I landed here in America, I started working. I started as a secretary at a private firm and later did clerical work at I B M. Now I am retired for almost twenty years due to my cancer complications.
Your Mesothelioma?
Yeah.
Okay, and who all are there in your family?

Well currently I am alone without any companion. I am divorced. I have a son who lives in Santa Cruz he has grand children, but I have not seen them, I am trying to get in touch with them. I want to see my grandkids.
Other than him I have a brother and a sister both are healthy and living their life we don't talk much.
Okay.
And do you drink or smoke?
Hm, nothing significant.
Any funny drugs like heroine or coke?
No.
Okay.

conversations.context: Fever of unknown origin.

dialogue.message: So what brings you in today?
Ugh.
I'm guessing you're not feeling too great.
You got that right. I've had a fever on and off for the past few days.
When was the last time you took your temperature?
Right before I drove here.
I see. Did the nurse take your temperature when you came in?
Yes, she did.
Have you been experiencing cold like symptoms, such as cough, nasal congestion, headache, or nausea?
Um no not really.
Have you tried taking any medicine to help with the fever?
Yeah. I've taken Tylenol and that's helped a bit.
Have you had recent sick contacts?
I don't think so. I live with three other roommates and they seem fine.

conversations.context: The patient is a 10-year-old boy who has been a toe walker since he started ambulating at about a year.  The patient had some mild hamstring tightness with his popliteal angle of approximately 20 degrees bilaterally.  He does not walk with a crouched gait but does toe walk.  Given his tightness, surgery versus observation was recommended to the family.  Family however wanted to correct his toe walking.  Surgery was then discussed.  Risks of surgery include risks of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremities, failure to resolve toe walking, possible stiffness, cast, and cast problems.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to above surgical plan.

dialogue.message: Can you tell me more about your son, please?
Guest_family: Sure, he's ten years old now.
How long has he used his walker?
Guest_family: Well, he's been using that since he started walking.
How old was he when he started walking?
Guest_family: He was about a year old.
Good, what seems to be the problem today?
Guest_family: He keeps complaining about the back of his legs being tight.
Can you sit on the table, young man? Yes, I'm bending his legs, we call this the popliteal angle, and both sides flex to only about twenty.
Guest_family: Where should that be normally?
He should be able to get to ninety.
Guest_family: What can we do about this?
I think we should do surgery on this leg. How does he walk? Can I see?
Guest_family: Well, just look at him.
Yes, he does not walk with a crouched pattern, but he is toe walking.
Guest_family: Can we correct that instead of the hamstring tightness?
Well, I believe he should have surgery on the hamstring, as well.
Guest_family: Okay, right now we want to do surgery to fix his walking. What are the risks of infection?

They're low, historically, they're less than one percent. The risks include anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and the motion of walking, and it may also not always cure the toe walking. There is also possible stiffness after wearing the cast and other cast issues.
Guest_family: Okay, and will be under anesthesia during this? Is this worth it?
Absolutely, he won't feel a thing. It is worth it because the chances of the risks happening are low.
Guest_family: Yes, we'd like to do the procedure. Let me text my husband really quick. Okay, yes, my husband agrees.

conversations.context: This is a 49-year-old white male who sustained a traumatic injury to his left posterior thighthis past year while in ABCD.  He sustained an injury from the patellar from a boat while in the water.  He was air lifted actually up to XYZ Hospital and underwent extensive surgery.  He still has an external fixation on it for the healing fractures in the leg and has undergone grafting and full thickness skin grafting closure to a large defect in his left posterior thigh, which is nearly healed right in the gluteal fold on that left area.  In several areas right along the graft site and low in the leg, the patient has several areas of hypergranulation tissue.  He has some drainage from these areas.  There are no signs and symptoms of infection.  He is referred to us to help him get those areas under control.

dialogue.message: Hello, sir. Before we begin your visit, could you verify your age and ethnicity for me, please?
I'm forty nine years old, and I identify as white.
Thank you. What brought you in today?
I was referred to you so that I could get whatever's wrong with me under control.
I see. What seems to be happening?
I hurt the back of my leg pretty bad this past year when I was in A B C D.
What part of your leg?
The back of my left thigh.
I see. So just the leg?
I also hurt my kneecap from a boat when I was out in the water fishing.
Was that severe?
It was a whole show. A helicopter came down and swooped me to X Y Z Hospital, where I got surgery.
I can see you still have an external fixation on your knee so that the fracture heals. Did the hospital give you a report on the surgery?
Yeah, they did. Here you go.

Thank you. Let me take a look. So, it looks like you underwent grafting and full thickness skin grafting for closure for a large defect in your left posterior thigh. That seems to be healed in the gluteal fold on the left area.
Yeah. Whatever that means.
Let me examine the area.
Go for it.
I can see several areas that have hypergranulation tissues around the graft site and low in the leg.
Is that bad?
I don't think so. Are you feeling any symptoms of a fever or anything?
No, I'm not.
That's good. You don't have any infections then.

conversations.context: The patient is a 76-year-old female who was referred to us from Dr. X for left flank pain.  The patient was found to have a left ureteral stone measuring about 1.3 cm in size per the patient's history.  The patient has had pain in the abdomen and across the back for the last four to five days.  The patient has some nausea and vomiting.  The patient wants something done for the stone.  The patient denies any hematuria, dysuria, burning or pain.  The patient denies any fevers.

dialogue.message: Welcome to the clinic, ma'am. I am Doctor Smith.
Thank you. It is nice to meet you.
Doctor X referred you to us, is that correct?
Yes. He is my primary care doctor.
It looks like you have a birthday coming up. Happy early birthday!
Thank you. Yes, I am going to be seventy seven.
Doctor Kim's notes said that you have had pain in the left flank pain. Can you tell me more about the pain?
Yes. The pain started four or five days ago. It has been in my stomach and through to my back, on the left side. Right here.
Okay. Have you had any nausea or vomiting?
Yes. I had some nausea, and I threw up a few times.
Have you noticed any blood, pain and or burning during urination?
No.
Any fever or chills?
No.
I have the ultrasound results that Doctor X ordered the other day.  The ultrasound found a stone in your left ureteral. The stone is about one point three C M in size.
Is there some thing we can do to remove it? I really want this taken care of.
Yes. Let us go over the treatment options.

conversations.context: The patient is in complaining of headaches and dizzy spells, as well as a new little rash on the medial right calf.  She describes her dizziness as both vertigo and lightheadedness.  She does not have a headache at present but has some intermittent headaches, neck pains, and generalized myalgias.  She has noticed a few more bruises on her legs.  No fever or chills with slight cough.  She has had more chest pains but not at present.  She does have a little bit of nausea but no vomiting or diarrhea.  She complains of some left shoulder tenderness and discomfort.  She reports her blood sugar today after lunch was 155.

dialogue.message: Hello, miss. How can I help you today? The nurse said the matter was urgent.
Yes, I have been having dizzy spells. I have also noticed a new rash on my right calf.
Can you describe what type of dizzy spells you are having? What do they feel like?
It is general dizziness and vertigo. I am also lightheaded during the spells.
Are you feeling okay right now or are you experiencing symptoms?
I am having headaches off and on randomly, but nothing right now. The neck pain and muscle aches also are intermittent.
Let me take a look at the rash on your legs. Are the bruises new?
They are new, I think. I have noticed them more than usual.
In the past couple days have you had a fever or chills?
No, nothing like that.
What about chest pains?
I have had some tightness in my chest, but not right now.
Does the dizziness make you nauseous?
Yes, but I have not had to throw up or anything.
What about diarrhea?
No, thank goodness.
Are there any parts of your body that are hurting?
I do have some left shoulder pain. Not so much painful, but it is uncomfortable and tender.

Have you measured your blood sugar at all? I ask because the notes state there is a history of gestational diabetes and when blood sugars are out of the normal limits this can cause some of the symptoms you are having.
I measured it today. After lunch it was one fifty five.

conversations.context: This is a 30-year-old female patient presenting with the above chief complaint. She has a history of having had a similar problem last year which resolved in about three treatments. She appears to have residual from spina bifida, thus spending most of her time in a wheelchair. She relates recently she has been spending up to 16 hours a day in a wheelchair. She has developed a pressure decubitus on her right trochanter ischial area of several weeks' duration. She is now presenting for evaluation and management of same. Denies any chills or fever, any other symptoms.

dialogue.message: How are you, Mary?
I am okay, I have got this ulcer on my right hip again.
Oh, is it like the one you got last time?
Pretty much.
Oh, I remember that one. It took almost three treatment cycles to get resolved.
Yeah. They keep saying I have some hidden split in my spine still.
Yeah, it looks like you have residual spina bifida.
I am just so frustrated sitting in my wheelchair. I am spending around sixteen hours a day in this wheelchair.
I think, that is the reason you developed this pressure ulcer. It appears to be on the right trochanter area. In simple terms you have developed a pressure sore on the outer part of your hip.
Yeah, I recently celebrated my thirtieth birthday just sitting in my wheelchair the whole day.
Oh, I am sorry dear. So, how long since you have had this ulcer?
It's been several weeks, so I thought I should get it checked.
Yeah, good thing you came. We need to treat it. Did you experience any chills or fever?
No.
Any other symptoms?
No.

conversations.context: Chest x-ray revealed a diffuse pulmonary edema.

dialogue.message: Your chest x ray showed diffuse pulmonary edema. This means that you have fluid in your lungs. That would explain your chest pain and the difficulies with your breathing. I would like to start you off with a course of antibiotics to prevent any possible infection. I will also send in a prescription for Furosemide. It will reduce the fluid accumulation in your lungs. Do you have any questions?
When should I start to feel better?
You should start to feel better within three to five days.

conversations.context: Mom's nipples are currently cracked and bleeding.  Mom has also noticed some mild umbilical discharge as well as some mild discharge from the penile area.  He is status post a circumcision.  Otherwise, review of systems is negative.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: My nipples are cracked, and they are bleeding.
Oh, I am so sorry to hear that.
Guest_family: He has some fluid coming out of his belly button as well as his penis.
Okay I will look at it. But other than that, everything else looks good? Any other problems related to circumcision?
Guest_family: No, no other issues.

conversations.context: This is a 56-year-old female who has pain in her legs at nighttime and when she gets up it comes and goes, radiates from her buttocks to her legs, sometimes it is her ankle.  She has noticed it since she has been on Lipitor.  She has had some night sweats occasionally.  She has had a little bit of fever and nausea.  She has noticed her blood sugars have been low.  She has lost over 30 pounds after exercising doing water aerobics at Genesis in Wichita.  She has noticed her fasting blood sugars have been ranging from 100 to 120.  Blood sugars one and a half hours after meals have been 185.  She is coming in for a diabetic checkup in one month and wants lab prior to that time.  She has been eating more meat recently and has not been on a diet for cholesterol.

dialogue.message: How old are you? What brings you here today?
I am fifty six years old. I am here for this pain in my legs. It hurts mostly in the night.
Does changing positions helps you?
Yeah, it helps. Whenever I stand it just goes away.
Is it only in your legs or it starts there and goes somewhere else as well?
It normally starts in my hips and then it goes down my leg and sometimes into my ankles as well.
When did you first notice it?
It all started after taking that medication. What is it called? Something with L? Yeah, Lipitor.
Have you ever noticed any night sweats?
Sometimes I do sweat at night.
Any other issue? Anything else going on? Your body temperature is a little on the higher end.
Yeah, I do feel feverish and have nausea as well.
How are your sugar numbers?
They have been low for quite some time. You know, I have started going to Genesis in Wichita and I've been doing water aerobics. And you know what? Surprisingly, I have lost thirty pounds.
That's good. How much is your fasting sugar?
Anywhere between a hundred to one hundred and twenty. I check them one and a half hours after meals as well. They are, they have been one hundred and eighty five regularly.
Okay.
Yeah. I have a request to make. I will be coming for my diabetic checkup in one month. Can we do all the labs before that?
Yeah, sure, that's a great idea. I should tell my assistant and they will call you for labs before your appointment for diabetes checkup.
Anything else going on? How is everything else?
I tried to control my cholesterol with diet, but it didn't help. I cannot keep on dieting. It is just not my thing. I have started eating more meat though. I feel full after that.

conversations.context: Father died from CA at the age of 79.  Mother died from postoperative infection at the age of 81.  Brother died from pancreatitis at the age of 40 and had a prior history of mental illness.  Father also had a prior history of lung cancer.  Mother had a history of breast cancer.  Father also had glaucoma.  He does not have any living siblings.  Friend died a year and half ago.

dialogue.message: Hi there! I am Doctor Smith.
Hello! It is nice to meet you.
Let's start with your family medical history.

My mother had breast cancer. My father had lung cancer that ended up taking his life. He was seventy nine when he passed. My mother also passed but not from an illness but from an infection she got after having an elective surgery.
I am so sorry for your loss. How old was your mother when she passed?
Thank you. She was eighty one when she passed. I am an orphan now. My only living sibling died at forty. He had a hard life. He struggled with mental illness.
How did your brother pass away?
He had pancreatitis. Oh, my dad had glaucoma.
You have had a lot of loss.
Yes, I have. My good friend passed away a year and a half ago. It has been a lot.
I have a support group I can refer you to for people to have been through loss. Would you be interested a referral, sir?
Yes. I would like that. Thank you.

conversations.context: A 47-year-old Latin American man presented to the emergency room after being told to come in for a high potassium value drawn the previous day. He had gone to an outside clinic the day prior to presentation complaining of weakness and fatigue. Labs drawn there revealed a potassium of 7.0 and he was told to come here for further evaluation. At time of his assessment in the emergency room, he noted general malaise and fatigue for eight months. Over this same time period he had subjective fevers and chills, night sweats, and a twenty-pound weight loss. He described anorexia with occasional nausea and vomiting of non-bilious material along with a feeling of light-headedness that occurred shortly after standing from a sitting or lying position. He denied a productive cough but did note chronic left sided upper back pain located in the ribs that was worse with cough and better with massage. He denied orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea but did become dyspneic after walking 2-3 blocks where before he had been able to jog 2-3 miles. He also noted that over the past year his left testicle had been getting progressively more swollen and painful. He had been seen for this at the onset of symptoms and given a course of antibiotics without improvement. Over the last several months there had been chronic drainage of yellowish material from this testicle. He denied trauma to this area. He denied diarrhea or constipation, changes in his urinary habits, rashes or skin changes, arthritis, arthralgias, abdominal pain, headache or visual changes.

dialogue.message: I will ask some simple questions, okay?
Hm
How old are you and how would you define yourself in terms of ethnicity?
Well, I am forty seven and would proudly call myself as Latin American.
Great. What brings you to the emergency room?
I had a blood test before and then it came out to be high potassium. I also went to a regular clinic the other day as I was feeling very weak and extremely tired.
Okay.

My potassium came out to be seven and it was highlighted in red. That really scared me, so I wanted to know everything what's going on inside me. I told the emergency doctors too that all these weakness and tiredness is going on for more than half a year.
Did you noticed any other symptoms other than weakness?

Yes, there was the fever and chills. I was sweating a lot in the nights, and I also had weight loss of around twenty pounds. During that time, I sometimes have nausea and was throwing up a lot. I was not eating. I always felt dizzy every time I tried to stand.
Did you have wet cough?
No, not wet cough but I did notice back pain gets intense on the upper side whenever I coughed, like in my ribs. I normally massage that area and it gets better.
Any shortness of breath?
Nope.
How about while sleeping or doing something else?

Not while sleeping, but I did notice that if I'm walking for two to three blocks then I get out of breath easily. Previously it was not like this. I used to jog for two to three miles without even a single breath loss.
I noticed one more thing. I feel like my balls on one side are getting big.
Which side left or right?
I think its left.
For how long?
I guess over the past year. I did see someone when all of this started, and he put me on some antibiotics, but nothing changed. For last few months there is yellow fluid coming out of it too.
Did you ever get any type of injury in the area?
No.
What about your bowel movements?
Nope everything is as usual.
Any change in urinary habits?
Nope.
Any changes in your skin? Any rash? Any kind of eyesight issue?
Nope, no changes.
What about pain? Like headache or any joint pain?
Nope, no pain anywhere.

conversations.context: The patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.  The patient states that he was working in his garage over the past few days when he noticed some redness and edema in his right foot.  He notes some itching as well as increasing pain and redness in the right foot and presented to ABCD General Hospital Emergency Room.  He was evaluated by the Emergency Room staff as well as the medical team and the Department of Orthopedics.  It was noted upon x-ray a foreign body in his foot and he had significant amount of cellulitis as well ________ right lower extremity.  After a long discussion held with the patient, it was elected to proceed with irrigation debridement and removal of the foreign body.

dialogue.message: Good morning, sir. You're sixty one years old, correct?
Good morning, doctor. Yes, that's correct.
Great, and you identify as Caucasian, right?
Yes, that's correct as well.
Thank you, do you have any medical conditions that I should know about?
Yes, I have diabetes.
How are you handling your diabetes?
Well, I've had diabetes for a long time but had never been treated for it.
Okay, thank you for telling me. What seems to be the problem today?
I've been working in my garage over the past few days, and I have this redness and swelling in my right foot.
Do you have any itchiness or pain?
Yes, and it's getting worse.
Have you seen any other doctors about this?
Um, yes. I went to the A B C D General Hospital E R and they gave me an evaluation there.
Do you have any images from this visit?
Um, yes. I have them right here.
Okay, these show a foreign body in the foot.
But what about all the stuff on the outside of my foot?
Well, that's consistent with cellulitis.
What's that?
It's a skin infection we clean it up in surgery.
What kind of procedure can we do?
We should do an irrigation debridement for the cellulitis, and remove the foreign body. I think that will really help.
Yes, I agree, doctor.

conversations.context: The patient is accompanied with his wife.

dialogue.message: Hello, sir. How are you doing today?
I'm flustered. I brought my wife so she can speak for me.
Hello, ma'am. What seems to be the problem with your husband?
Guest_family: He's been having some problems with his skin in his private region. He's too shy to talk about it himself.

conversations.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No history of fever, rigors, or chills except for recent fever and rigors. HEENT:  No history of cataract or glaucoma. RESPIRATORY:  Shortness of breath.  No pneumonia or valley fever. GASTROINTESTINAL:  Nausea and vomiting.  No hematemesis or melena. UROLOGICAL:  Frequency, urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No muscle weakness. SKIN:  None significant. NEUROLOGICAL:  No TIA or CVA.  No seizure disorder. PSYCHOLOGICAL:  No anxiety or depression.  HEMATOLOGICAL:  None significant.

dialogue.message: How long have you been running a fever?
It's been on and off for a few days now. I'm also having chills.
Have you taken anything for the fever?
Tylenol and Advil. I've been taking them interchangeably.
When was the last time you took your temperature?
An hour ago. The thermometer read one O one point four.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or others?
I've been having a stronger urge to pee a lot more than usual. Not sure if that's related.
It could be. We're still waiting on your urine results. Do you have a history of cataracts or glaucoma?
No.
Okay, great. Any signs of pneumonia or valley fever?
Nothing of the sort.
What about blood in your vomit or feces?
Nope.
Any neurological symptoms like T I A or C V A? That is slurred speech or stroke symptoms.
Luckily, no. I don't have seizures or anything like that.
Great to here. With the pandemic I wanted to check on your mental health too. Any depression or anxiety?
I have always been a homebody. This is normal for me. Nothing like that in my head.
Cool. Do you have any issues with blood disorders?
Nothing like that.

conversations.context: The patient is a 59-year-old gentleman who is now approximately 4 months status post percutaneous screw fixation of Schatzker IV tibial plateau fracture and nonoperative management of second through fifth metatarsal head fractures.  He is currently at home and has left nursing home facility.  He states that his pain is well controlled. He has been working with physical therapy two to three times a week.  He has had no drainage or fever.  He has noticed some increasing paresthesias in his bilateral feet but has a history of spinal stenosis with lower extremity neuropathy.

dialogue.message: Hello, sir. So, remind me, how long ago was your procedure?
Let me think. Now, it's been about four months. I just turned fifty nine.
Okay, and just to refresh your memory, we did a percutaneous screw fixation of a Schatzker I V tibial plateau fracture, and we've managed those toe fractures nonoperatively.
Which toes did I break?
You broke your second and fifth toes.
Do you have the x rays? Can I see where the breaks are?
Absolutely, if you look here, right here is where the breaks are. These are called the metatarsal heads.
Wow, that's right where it hurts.
Yep, and where are you living now?
Thankfully, I left the nursing home, and I'm back in my own house now.
That's really good. Are you in any pain today?
No, not today.
Great, have you been going to P T?
Yeah, I've been going about two or three times a week.
Are there any signs of infection, like drainage from the incision?
Nope, the wound healed up nicely. I'll be able to wear shorts again.
Great, are you having any fever symptoms, like cough, runny nose, sore throat, fatigue, anything like that?
No, but I have had some tingling in both my feet. I don't know if its related to surgery. If I'm remembering the names right, um, I have a history of spinal stenosis and neuropathy in my legs.
With your history of spinal stenosis, the broken toes, and the surgery, that's a pretty normal side effect.

conversations.context: The patient is here for a follow-up.  The patient has a history of lupus, currently on Plaquenil 200-mg b.i.d.  Eye report was noted and appreciated.  The patient states that she is having some aches and pains of the hands and elbows that started recently a few weeks ago.  She denied having any trauma.  She states that the pain is bothering her.  She denies having any fevers, chills, or any joint effusion or swelling at this point.  She noted also that there is some increase in her hair loss in the recent times.

dialogue.message: Hello, this is your follow up visit, right? Welcome back! Have you been taking your Plaquenil for lupus, ma'am?
Yeah, I am.
Your prescription is two hundred M G twice a day, correct?
Yeah, that's it.
Do you have your eye report with you today?
Yes, doctor. Here you go.
Good, thank you, what seems to be the problem today?
Well, I'm having some aches and pains in my hands and elbows.
When did this pain start?
It's been a few weeks now.
Is there any associated trauma? Did you fall?
No, no falls or anything. It just started one day, and it's really bothering me.
Are you having any fever or chills, or cold or flu like symptoms?
No, I'm not.
How about swelling? Are any of your joints swollen?
No, everything is normal there. Of note, I have been losing a lot of hair recently.
Okay, that's interesting.

conversations.context: All siblings are on antibiotics for ear infections and URIs.

dialogue.message: How're your other children doing?
Guest_family: Not so wonderful. They're all on antibiotics.
For the same?
Guest_family: Yep. They all have ear infections and chest colds.
Your hands are full then.
Guest_family: Tell me about it, doctor. I can't seem to catch much of a break.
It's definitely been a tough winter for you and your family.

conversations.context: 1.  Disseminated CMV infection with possible CMV pneumonitis. 2.  Polymyositis on immunosuppressive therapy (methotrexate and prednisone).

dialogue.message: Guest_clinician: Is the patient being admitted for disseminated C M V infection?
Yes. I suspect they have possible C M V pneumonitis as well.
Guest_clinician: Are they on immunosuppressants?
Yes. They have polymyositis and they're taking Prednisone and Methotrexate.
Guest_clinician: Got it.

conversations.context: I was asked to see the patient for C. diff colitis.

dialogue.message: You are referred for some abdominal infection right?
Yes, they told me I might have C Diff?
Yes that's what we will evaluate you for.

conversations.context: Nothing significant.

dialogue.message: Have you had a recent vaccination?
I had a flu shot last winter but I have not had and recent vaccines.
Do you have any planned in the near future?
I was going to get another flu shot but I don't think I am due for that for another three months.
Great.

conversations.context: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, altered mental status.

dialogue.message: How's he doing?
Guest_family: Not so great. He's been out of it. He hasn't been acting like himself.
How long has it been since you noticed any behavioral changes?
Guest_family: A few days now.
Is he complaining of any pain?
Guest_family: Yeah he's been-
He's been?
Guest_family: Sorry, my phone was on vibrate and I had to turn it off.
No problem.
Guest_family: He's been pointing to his stomach and saying it hurts.
Is he having any other symptoms?
Guest_family: He's told me he feels queasy. I took his temperature the other night and he was running a fever of one O two.
Any vomiting with the nausea?
Guest_family: Yeah, he's thrown up a handful of times.

conversations.context: The patient is now approximately week status post removal of Ex-Fix from the right knee with an MUA following open reduction internal fixation of right tibial plateau fracture.  The patient states that this pain is well controlled.  He has had no fevers, chills or night sweats.  He has had some mild drainage from his pin sites.  He just started doing range of motion type exercises for his right knee.  He has had no numbness or tingling.

dialogue.message: Good morning, sir. Remind me please, when was your surgery?
Hello, doctor. It was about a week ago now.
Great, and just to remind you, you had a removal of Ex Fix from the right knee with an M U A following O R I F of a right tibial plateau fracture.
Yes, that all sounds familiar. What's M U A?
It stands for manipulation under anesthesia. We bent the knee in order to forcibly break up some scar tissue.
Oh, wow.
Yeah, it's great, eliminates some need for P T in fact. How are you doing today?
Overall, my pain is under control.
Are you having any flu like, or infection symptoms?
No, nothing like that at all.
So, no fever, or chills, or sweating at night.
Yeah, nothing like that.
Great. I see you're having some drainage from the pin sites, but that doesn't bother me too much.
Okay, good. I was getting worried.
No need to worry. Are you doing your range of motion exercises? Those are imperative.
Yes, doctor. I am.
Good, and do you have any numbness or tingling?
No, doctor. I don't have any of that.

conversations.context: The patient is a 5-year, 8-month-old male who presented to me direct from ED with distracted left lateral condyle fracture.  He underwent screw compression for the fracture in October 2007.  The fracture has subsequently healed and the patient presents for hardware removal.  The risks and benefits of surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery include the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of extremity, failure of removal of hardware, failure to relieve pain or improved range of motion.  All questions were answered and the family agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Hello. How are you both doing today?
Guest_family: We're doing great. The E D told us to come here. We're here to see if we could get the stuff in his leg taken out.
I see. Did he have a fracture before?
Guest_family: Yeah, he did. Here's the report from the surgery from October two thousand and seven.
Great. Let me take a look. It looks like he had a distracted left lateral condyle fracture. He then underwent screw compression to fix the fracture, correct?
Guest_family: That's correct.
Perfect. So, now we just have to remove the hardware that was used to fix the fracture, right?
Guest_family: Yeah, that's correct. What are the risks of the surgery?
The risks include the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of extremity, failure of removal of hardware, failure to relieve pain or improved range of motion.
Guest_family: Oh, wow. That's a lot. Could you go over the benefits?
Of course. Before I do, I just need to confirm your son's age.
Guest_family: He can tell you.
Hi. I'm five years old. My birthday is in four months.
Thank you. Happy almost birthday.
Guest_family: He gets excited about birthdays. I just have a few more questions, but it looks like we're going to go through with the surgery.

conversations.context: Mom brings patient in today because of sore throat starting last night.  Eyes have been very puffy.  He has taken some Benadryl when all of this congestion started but with a sudden onset just yesterday.  He has had low-grade fever and just felt very run down, appearing very tired.  He is still eating and drinking well, and his voice has been hoarse but no coughing.  No shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea or abdominal pain.

dialogue.message: What brings this little guy in today?

Guest_family: He's been complaining of a sore throat since last night. I noticed his eyes were really puffy before he went to bed and that's when I gave him some Benadryl. At that time, he also seemed nasally.
Sorry to hear that. Did he have a fever?
Guest_family: When I took his temperature last night, it was one O one.
And did you give him anything for the fever?
Guest_family: I was worried about giving him something on top of the Benadryl.
I see. And how has he felt otherwise?
Guest_family: He appears more sluggish than usual. Fortunately, he's eating and drinking well.
Has he been coughing at all?
Guest_family: No, but his voice has been a kind of raspy.
Any shortness of breath?
Guest_family: Um no.
How about any episodes of vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach pain?
Guest_family: No, I don't think so.

conversations.context: The child has not been having any coughing, gagging, vomiting, or other symptoms.  Acting perfectly normal.  Family mostly noted that she had spilled it on the ground around her, had it on her hands, and on her clothes.  They did not witness that she ingested any, but did not see anything her mouth.

dialogue.message: Have you notied her behaving strangly in any way?
Guest_family: No. She is acting perfectly normal.
Has she been gagging, coughing, vomiting or any other symptoms?
Guest_family: No. The only thing that I noticed is that she spilled the liquid all over her clothes, the ground and on her hands.
Did you see her ingest any of the fluid?
Guest_family: No. We didn't see her put it in her mouth. I looked inside her mouth and didn't see anything.

conversations.context: This is a 43-year-old black man with no apparent past medical history who presented to the emergency room with the chief complaint of weakness, malaise and dyspnea on exertion for approximately one month.  The patient also reports a 15-pound weight loss.  He denies fever, chills and sweats.  He denies cough and diarrhea.  He has mild anorexia.

dialogue.message: Any past medical problems I should know of?

No, ma'am. I am forty three and this is the first time I have had a major issue. It's only been this past month where I've felt weaker than usual. I'm much more tired and short of breath whenever I move around.
Any recent weight loss?
Yeah, I actually lost about fifteen pounds in less than two or three months.
How's your appetite? Any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea?
Appetite is pretty fine. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
How about fever, chills, sweats, cough?
No, ma'am.
And any chest pain with your shortness of breath?
No, ma'am.

conversations.context: Headache and pain in the neck and lower back.

dialogue.message: How're you feeling today?
Not great.
I'm sorry, why is that?
I've had a headache all week along with neck and lower back pain.
How would you describe the headache?
Throbbing pain.
Is it constant?
It comes and goes for the most part.
How would you rate it on a scale of ten with ten being the worst?
A seven or eight.
Do you have a headache currently?
No, not right this second.
Have you taken-
Anything for the pain?
Yes.
I took some Ibuprofen, but it doesn't seem to be helping much.
Any other symptoms associated with the headache, such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light?
No, not really. I don't feel like I have a cold or anything.
Any recent injuries to the head?
No.
And your neck and lower back pain, is this new?
Eh I can't say. It's been bothering me for some time now, but the pain feels a bit different.
How so?
I don't really know. It's more pronounced.

conversations.context: Soon after birth for treatment of an inperforated anus and curvature of the penis.  At the age of 70 had another penile operation.  At the age of 27 and 28 he had repeat operations to correct this.  He did have complications of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism with one of those operations.  He has had procedures in the past for hypospadias, underwent an operation in 1988 to remove some tissue block in the anus.  In January of 1991 underwent cystoscopy.  He was hospitalized in 1970 for treatment of urinary tract infection.  In 2001, left rotator cuff repair with acromioplasty and distal clavicle resection.  In 2001, colonoscopy that was normal.  In 2001, prostate biopsy that showed chronic prostatitis.  In 2003, left inguinal hernia repair with MESH.

dialogue.message: I would like to get a detailed history of your inperforated anus and the curvature of the penis. It is a genetic condition. And do you know if you had surgery soon after birth?
Yeah, my mother said that I had to have surgery after she gave birth to me.
Do you know all the surgeries that you have had for this?
I don't know if I have all of them written down, but I do have most of them here.
Oh, good you have a list.
Yeah. I was hospitalized in nineteen seventy for a U T I. That is when the problems started happening. It was a really bad infection.
Okay.
In nineteen eighty eight I the tissue removed from the anus. There was a blockage. They also did an operation in the shaft of the penis too.
I bet things improved after that surgery.
It did. I have here in January of nineteen ninety one I had a cystoscopy to remove a blockage.
Um hum.
In two thousand and one I had a colonoscopy that was normal. Later that year I had a biopsy of my prostate.
What did the biopsy show?
They said I had severe inflammation in the prostate. I was never told that cause of the inflammation.
Okay. Any other surgeries for your condition?

Oh yeah. I had that same procedure done again when I was twenty seven and twenty eight. The same one that I had as a newborn. I had a third surgery when I was seventy with just a correction of the shaft area.
Um hum. Any other surgeries unrelated to your condition?

Yeah. I have it written down here. In two thousand and one there was a left rotator cuff repair with acromioplasty and distal clavicle resection and in two thousand and three I had a left inguinal hernia repair with M E S H. That is what my notes say.
Have you ever had any complications during any of your surgeries?
Yeah, I did. I have a blood clot that apparently went into my lungs. I was very scary.
That is very scary.

conversations.context: 21 y/o RHM complained of gradual onset numbness and incoordination of both lower extremities beginning approximately 11/5/96. The symptoms became maximal over a 12-24 hour period and have not changed since. The symptoms consist of tingling in the distal lower extremities approximately half way up the calf bilaterally. He noted decreased coordination of both lower extremities which he thought might be due to uncertainty as to where his feet were being placed in space. He denied bowel/bladder problems, or weakness or numbness elsewhere. Hot showers may improve his symptoms. He has suffered no recent flu-like illness. Past medical and family histories are unremarkable. He was on no medications.

dialogue.message: How old are you, young man?
I am twenty one.
Are you right handed or left handed?
I am right handed.
So, tell me what brings you here today?

Everything started on the fifth of November. Then after I saw the gradual increase in my symptoms. So it was all like numbness. I could not feel my legs. They felt numb all the time and there was no coordination between them, and it also affected my walk. All these symptoms were at their limit in just like a half day or more. It is continuing the same way since then. I also feel like somebody is putting pins and needles on my legs approximately  halfway up the calf on both sides.
You said that you felt decreased coordination or less coordination between your legs, right?
Yeah, that's right. It totally feels like I'm walking in space and don't know where to put my next step. I have no up and down spatial awareness.
Do you have any issue with the bowel movements?
Nope.
What about this weakness or the numbness anywhere else except your legs?
No, it's only in the legs.
Did anything help you with those symptoms?
Well, sometimes, you see, hot showers made me feel better, but it is like only sometimes.
Any recent flu like symptoms?
Nope.
Did anyone in your family have anything like that or any other medical issues that was like going on in your family?
Nope.
Did you have any surgery before?
Nope.
What about any other major health issues in the past?
No, no medical issues.
Are you taking any kind of medication for anything?
No medications.

conversations.context: Negative for rheumatic fever.  The patient has usual childhood illnesses.

dialogue.message: Do you have any history of rheumatic fever as a child?
No.
Any history of anything other then usual childhood illnesses?
No.

conversations.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No history of fever, rigors, or chills. HEENT:  No history of cataract, blurring vision, or glaucoma.  RESPIRATORY:  Shortness of breath.  No pneumonia or valley fever. GASTROINTESTINAL:  No epigastric discomfort, hematemesis, or melena. UROLOGICAL:  No frequency or urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No arthritis or muscle weakness. CNS:  No TIA.  No CVA.  No seizure disorder. ENDOCRINE:  Nonsignificant. HEMATOLOGICAL:  Nonsignificant.

dialogue.message: Any fever, chills or rigors?
No.
Any blurring of vision or history of glaucoma or cataract?
No.
Did you experience any shortness of breath?
No.
Any stomach discomfort?
No.
Did you observe blood in your stool or in vomit?
No, nothing like that.
Okay, good. Did you notice any increase in your urine frequency or urgency?
No.
Do you feel any muscle weakness or tiredness?
No, nothing of that sort.
Any known history of arthritis?
Nope.
And no fever due to any fungal infection or anything, right? Like valley fever?
No, nothing of that sort.
Any history of pneumonia?
No.
And I am looking at your chart, so no history of stroke, C V A, or any seizure disorder.
That's correct.
No thyroid or hormone related problem?
No.
And you do not have any blood disorders, right?
That is right.

conversations.context: The patient has multiple medical problems, for which she is under the care of Dr. X.  She has a history of chronic obstructive lung disease and a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease.  There is a history of anemia and there is a history of sciatica, which has been caused by arthritis.  The patient has had skin cancers, which have been treated with local excision.

dialogue.message: Hello, how are you?
I am good, Doctor.
So, what brings you here today?
Well, I have many medical issues and I see Doctor X for them, but I wanted a second opinion, so he referred me here.
Yeah, he is a good man! Don't worry we will take care of you.
Thank you.
So, let me start by getting your medical history.
Sure, I had skin cancer which was treated by removal of that part.
Okay.
Other than that, I have anemia and an acid reflux problem. I also have history of C O P D.
Alright.
I also suffer from sciatica which was caused mainly due to my arthritis.
I see.

conversations.context: Mr. Sample Patient returns to the Sample Clinic with the chief complaint of painful right heel.  The patient states that the heel has been painful for approximately two weeks, it is starts with the first step in the morning and gets worse with activity during the day.  The patient states that he is currently doing no treatment for it.  He states that most of his pain is along medial tubercle of the right calcaneus and extends to the medial arch.  The patient states that he has no change in the past medical history since his last visit and denies any fever, chills, vomiting, headache, chest, or shortness of breath.

dialogue.message: Welcome back to Sample Clinic, Mister Sample.
Good afternoon, doctor.
What seems to be the problem today, sir?
I'm having a lot of pain in my right heel.
How long have you had this pain?
Um, it's been about two weeks now.
When is the pain the worst?
Honestly, it starts with the first step first thing in the morning.
Does it get worse throughout the day?
Yes, it gets worse all day with activities.
What treatments have you had for this?
Well, nothing to date.
Where is your heel pain?
It's on the right heel, then it's on the inside bottom part of the heel and into the inside of the heel.
Do you have any change in your medical history since your last visit?
No, it's the same old same old.
Do you have any flu like symptoms?
Like fever or chills?
That, or vomiting or headaches.
Oh, no I don't have anything like that.
What about chest pain or shortness of breath?
Thankfully, no nothing like that.

conversations.context: The patient was an 8 pounds 13 ounces' term baby born 1 week early via a planned repeat C-section.  Mom denies any infections during pregnancy, except for thumb and toenail infections, treated with rubbing alcohol (mom denies any history of boils in the family).  GBS status was negative.  Mom smoked up to the last 5 months of the pregnancy.  Mom and dad both deny any sexually transmitted diseases or genital herpetic lesions.  Mom and baby were both discharged out of the hospital last 48 hours.  This patient has received no hospitalizations so far.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: Hi, how are you?
I am well, how's the baby? I see that he is eight pounds and thirteen ounces, and he was born viaâ€¦?
Guest_family: Yes, C section. Yeah, he is he has never been hospitalized. He was born a week early.
Okay, I would like to ask you some questions about the pregnancy and other history.
Guest_family: Yes, sure go ahead.
Great, have you had any infections during pregnancy like G B S or S T D infections?

Guest_family: No, I haven't, I only had thumb and toenail infections and we treated that with rubbing alcohol. We have a history of boils in the family, so I am not afraid of minor infections like this.
Did you smoke during pregnancy?
Guest_family: Yes, I did, but stopped after five months.
Sir, have you had any S T D while she was pregnant?
Guest_family_2: No, I was not diagnosed with anything unusual.
Great, so looks like you were discharged in forty eight hours and no more hospital stays for you.
Guest_family: That is correct.

conversations.context: Upper respiratory illness with apnea, possible pertussis.

dialogue.message: What's bringing her in today?
Guest_family: Oh, doctor. She hasn't been doing well at all.
Guest_family: I think she's actually gotten worse.
I understand. I'm sorry to hear that she hasn't been feeling well. Let me see what we can do for her today.
Guest_family: I haven't taken her temperature since this morning. It was one hundred and three degrees when she woke up.
What time did she wake up today?
Guest_family: Um, around eight I believe. She also suffers from apnea.
It looks like she has an upper respiratory infection.
Guest_family: Is she going to get better?
Yes, she should feel better once we start treating the infection. But I'm worried it may be pertussis.

conversations.context: The patient is a 10-year-old right-hand dominant male, who threw himself off a quad on 10/10/2007.  The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation of his left elbow fracture dislocation.  The patient also sustained a nondisplaced right glenoid neck fracture.  The patient's fracture has healed without incident, although he had significant postoperative stiffness for which he is undergoing physical therapy, as well as use of a Dynasplint.  The patient is neurologically intact distally.  Given the fact that his fracture has healed, surgery was recommended for hardware removal to decrease his irritation with elbow extension from the hardware.  Risks and benefits of the surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery included the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremities, failure to remove hardware, failure to relieve pain, continued postoperative stiffness.  All questions were answered and the parents agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Remind me, how did he hurt himself?
Guest_family_1: He was riding quads on October tenth two thousand seven when he got thrown off.
Yes, and we did O R I F on his fracture dislocation of the left elbow.
Guest_family_1: Yes, he also fractured the neck of his right glenoid, um, if I remember correctly.
Which hand does he write with?
Guest_family_1: He writes with his right hand.
Okay. That fracture appears to have healed very well; kids generally heal pretty well. How does it feel today?
Guest_family_1: Yes, he's only ten. He's been pretty stiff, so he's been going to P T, and using his Dynasplint.

That's good that he is already in P T. His left elbow fracture is healed, so we should do another surgery in order to remove that hardware. That may help decrease some of the irritation with elbow extension. He looks neurologically intact in terms of movement and reflexed in his wrist and hand.
Guest_family_1: Yes, I agree. What is the risk of infection of this surgery?
Historically, the risk of infection is less than one percent.
Guest_family_1: Oh, wow, that's low, how is that possible?

We'll use prophylactic antibiotics, this controls for infection, and helps keep everything clean. Other Risks include bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremities, failure to remove hardware, failure to relieve pain, and continued postoperative stiffness.
Guest_family_1: Wow, that's great, will be he asleep the entire time?
Yes, we'll use anesthesia, he won't feel a thing.
Guest_family_1: Will this fix his pain, for sure?
I can't guarantee it, he may still be in some pain.
Guest_family_1: Okay, what about you, dear? What do you think?
Guest_family_2: Yeah, I think we should do it, boys should be playing sports with their friends.

conversations.context: This is a 56-year-old female who comes in for a dietary consultation for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease and weight reduction.  The patient states that her husband has been diagnosed with high blood cholesterol as well.  She wants some support with some dietary recommendations to assist both of them in healthier eating.  The two of them live alone now, and she is used to cooking for large portions.  She is having a hard time adjusting to preparing food for the two of them.  She would like to do less food preparation, in fact.  She is starting a new job this week.

dialogue.message: Good afternoon, ma'am. Before we begin, may I ask how old you are?
Good afternoon, doctor. I'm fifty six years old, now.
Great, thank you. What seems to be the problem today, ma'am?
Well, I need some support for dietary recommendations for healthy eating for my husband and me.
Why would that be, ma'am?
Um, I have a lot going on, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, acid reflux, and I just want to lose some weight. My husband has high cholesterol too.
Tell me more about your eating habits, please.
Well, we live by ourselves now that our children are gone, but I'm used to cooking really large portions.
Are you struggling to make food for just two people?
Yes, that's a good way to put it. I'd like to just make less food, that way we're not so tempted to eat so much.
I understand, are you busy, do you work?
Well, I start a new job this week.

conversations.context: Allergic rhinitis.  Otherwise healthy 2-year-old young lady.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: What do you think doctor, what does she have?
Well, I think she has hay fever. Otherwise she looks like a healthy two year old.
Guest_family: Hm, okay.

conversations.context: Fever.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: Doctor can you check my baby boy?
Yes for sure.
Guest_family: He has a fever.

conversations.context: Diabetes type II uncontrolled.  Acute cystitis.

dialogue.message: Alright, I am looking at your urine report and it confirms what I was suspecting. You have a urinary tract infection.
I kind of knew it was a U T I. I have had it before, but nothing this painful and severe. I feel like I am going to die!
Oh yes, it is because you got something called as acute cystitis and its usually very painful and can cause some serious complications.
Well, is it because of my diabetes?
I am afraid I don't have better news for you, but your diabetes is out of control. It's way too high and you must be really careful. Are you taking your medicines?
Yes!
How bout diet?
Yeah, sometimes I don't care about my diet.

Well, you must watch your diet, you can't just be careless. I am going to change your diabetes medication. And let's start you on the antibiotic that should give you relief. Also stay hydrated drink plenty of fluids it will help you flush the infection out.
Alright, thank you!
Take care.

conversations.context: General:  No fevers, chills, or sweats.  No weight loss or weight gain. Cardiovascular:  No exertional chest pain, orthopnea, PND, or pedal edema.  No palpitations. Neurologic:  No paresis, paresthesias, or syncope. Eyes:  No double vision or blurred vision. Ears:  No tinnitus or decreased auditory acuity. ENT:  No allergy symptoms, such as rhinorrhea or sneezing. GI:  No indigestion, heartburn, or diarrhea.  No blood in the stools or black stools.  No change in bowel habits. GU:  No dysuria, hematuria, or pyuria.  No polyuria or nocturia.  Denies slow urinary stream. Psych:  No symptoms of depression or anxiety. Pulmonary:  No wheezing, cough, or sputum production. Skin:  No skin lesions or nonhealing lesions. Musculoskeletal:  No joint pain, bone pain, or back pain.  No erythema at the joints. Endocrine:  No heat or cold intolerance.  No polydipsia. Hematologic:  No easy bruising or easy bleeding.  No swollen lymph nodes.

dialogue.message: Let me examine you. Tell me, did you have any fever or chills, any sweating or that sort of thing?
Um no.
How about abnormal weight loss or weight gain?
No.
Are you experiencing any chest pain on exertion or shortness of breath normally or when you try to sleep?
No, no chest pain and shortness of breath.
Let me see your legs. They look good I don't see any pedal edema. Usually that happens due to excess water retention. Any palpitations?
No.
Any feeling of numbness or tingling? Did you faint or lose consciousness anytime?
No and no.
Okay, good!
Any double and or blurred vision?
No.
Any difficulty hearing or any wired continuous sound you may hear?
No.
Okay, um tell me if you had any um, allergies, or sneezing, or runny nose?
No, no really.
Okay, got it.
Any indigestion, or heart burn? Did you notice any blood in stool or black stool?
No.
Any diarrhea or vomiting?
Nope.
Are you feeling thirsty frequently?
No, just normal.
Okay.
And I see you got a urine test, so no pus cells or blood present.
Yes.
Any pain while passing urine though? Any blood?
No.
And how is the urine frequency? Do you have to wake up at night to urinate?
Well, my frequency is normal. I don't have to wake up at night for urinating.
How bout the stream while passing urine? You think it's normal or somewhat slow?
No, it's absolutely normal.
Okay, so any cough or cold like symptoms any sputum?
Nope.
No wheezing, right?
Yes, no wheezing.
I don't see any lesions, that's good. Any mood swings, feeling depressed or have anxiety?
No.
Any joint pain in the legs, back or anywhere?
Um no.
Okay, so no erythema in the joints. Any heat or cold intolerance?
No.
Okay, any difficulty swallowing? Let me check here, lymph nodes look fine. And do you bleed easily and does the bleeding stop normally?
Oh yes!
Do you bruise easy?
No, not really.
Okay. Any abnormal skin lesions?
No.

conversations.context: Last flu vaccine was given on 1999. Last pneumonia vaccine was given on 1996. Family Medical History: Father age 79, history of cerebrovascular accident (stroke) and hypertension. Mother history of CHF and emphysema that died at the age of 74. No brothers and sisters.

dialogue.message: Do you remember when your last flu vaccine was?
I don't remember what month, but it was in nineteen ninety nine.
Good, and do you remember your last pneumonia vaccine?
Let me look at my notes here, um, it was in nineteen ninety six.
Thank you, now, tell me more about your parents. Do you know their medical histories?
Let me think, my dad is still around, he had a stroke. Oh yeah, and he has high blood pressure.
How old is your father?
He's seventy nine now.
Good, what about your mother?
She died when she was seventy four, she had heart failure and emphysema.
I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have any brothers or sisters?
Thank you doctor, no, its just me and my Dad now.

conversations.context: 23-year-old Hispanic male who presented for evaluation of chronic abdominal pain. Patient described the pain as dull, achy, constant and located at the epigastric area with some radiation to the back. There are also occasional episodes of stabbing epigastric pain unrelated to meals lasting only minutes. Patient noted that the pain started approximately six months prior to this presentation. He self medicated "with over the counter" antacids and obtained some relief so he did not seek medical attention at that time. Two months prior to current presentation, he had worsening of his pain as well as occasional nausea and vomiting. At this time the patient was found to be H. pylori positive by serology and was treated with triple therapy for two weeks and continued on omeprazole without relief of his pain. The patient felt he had experienced a twenty-pound weight loss since his symptoms began but he also admitted to poor appetite. He stated that he had two to three loose bowel movements a day but denied melena or bright red blood per rectum. Patient denied NSAID use, ethanol abuse or hematemesis. Position did not affect the quality of the pain. Patient denied fever or flushing. He stated he was a very active and healthy individual prior to these recent problems.

dialogue.message: Hi, the weather outside is beautiful, did you get some sunshine?
Yes in fact I came in walking.
Great way to get some exercise in.
ok so what's going on?
I am having a bellyache.
Since when?
Oh, it's been a while now.
Can you tell me more about your pain like how did it start and what exactly are you feeling?
Ok so the pain started as dullache but it is constant right here in the middle upper part of my stomach. And sometimes it is moving to the back.
Can you tell me if it is stabbing pain and if it is related to any specific time of the day?
Sure, so i do get episodes of stabbing pain but they are not related to meals. Once the wave comes it lasts for only a minute or so.
Can you tell me when exactly you noted it?
Approximately six months back. I took over the counter antacids and got some relief so i did not go to doctor. But two months back it got worse, I do get occasional nausea and vomiting.
I can see that they found H pylori positive infection and treated you with triple drug therapy for two weeks and then gave you antacid omeprazole. But it did not improve your pain.
Yeah that's right.
Do you know I lost twenty pound of weight since all these symptoms began but i have been also admitted for poor appetite.
Ok tell me how are your bowel movements and if you see any blood in stools?
I get two to three loose bowel movements a day but no blood in stool or anywhere.
Are you taking any pain medication over the counter? Do you drink alcohol and maybe you are vomiting blood?
No no, nothing like that.
Can you tell me if any change in position changes the quality of pain? do you have any fever?
No position changing have no effect, no fever or anything.
Have you been exercising before all this?
Yes I have had very active and healthy lifestyle.

conversations.context: He has been congested for about three weeks ago.  Coughing now but no fevers.  No vomiting.  Review of systems is otherwise negative.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: Congestion and cough.
Oh, how long?
Guest_family: It's been three weeks now.
Okay.
Guest_family: He has been like this for so long, but nothing else.
How about fever nausea vomiting diarrhea?
Guest_family: No fever, no vomiting, nothing else.
Okay great.

conversations.context: The patient returns to the Pulmonary Medicine Clinic for followup evaluation of COPD and emphysema.  She was last seen in the clinic in March 2004.  Since that time, she has been hospitalized for psychiatric problems and now is in a nursing facility.  She is very frustrated with her living situation and would like to return to her own apartment, however, some believes she is to ill to care for herself. At the present time, respiratory status is relatively stable.  She is still short of breath with activity, but all-in-all her pulmonary disease has not changed significantly since her last visit.  She does have occasional cough and a small amount of sputum production.  No fever or chills.  No chest pains.

dialogue.message: Hello, miss. How are you doing today? It looks like we are evaluating C O P D and emphysema.
Yes, the last time I was seen in Pulmonary Medicine Clinic was March two thousand and four.
It has been quite some time. How are you feeling?
I have actually been hospitalized for psychiatric problems and now live in a nursing facility. Things have not been too great. I don't like living there.
I understand the frustration. When you live in a nursing facility you lose a lot of your freedom.
I want to live back in my apartment, but I know I am too ill to care for myself.
In spite of all of that how are your respiratory issues?
I feel pretty stable. I still have shortness of breath when I do activities, but with my condition I feel like that is something I will have to live with.
Unfortunately, that is the nature of the disease. I am happy to see that the pulmonary disease has not changed significantly since your last visit.
The only thing that seems to have changed is that I have a small cough and produce some mucus.
Okay. Do you have any fever or chills?
No, none of that.
Do you experience any chest pains? I want to check especially since you have been coughing up some mucus.
No, I luckily do not have any chest pains.

conversations.context: The patient is a 5-year-4-month-old male who presents for evaluation of feet.  He has been having significant feet pain with significant planovalgus deformity.  The patient was noted to have flexible vertical talus.  It was decided that the patient would benefit by subtalar arthrodesis, possible autograft, and Achilles lengthening.  This was explained to the mother in detail.  This is going to be a stabilizing measure and the patient will probably need additional surgery at a later day when his foot is more mature.  Risks of surgery include risks of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, hardware failure, need for other surgical procedures, need to be nonweightbearing for some time.  All questions were answered and the mother agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: How old is your son?
Guest_family: He is almost five and a half years old now.
What seems to be the problem?
Guest_family: He has a lot of pain about both feet, and if you look at it, it looks like his feet rotate inwards.
Okay, let me see, okay, um, he has rocker bottom feet.
Guest_family: Okay.
I believe he would benefit from a subtalar arthrodesis, possible autograft, and lengthening of the Achilles. I'll go over the details of that procedure right now.
Guest_family: Can we do the surgery soon?
Yes we can. But we'll probably need to do another procedure until his foot matures some more.   This is a stabilizing measure.
Guest_family: What are the risks of infection if we do the surgery?
Historically, the risk of infection is very low, usually less than one percent.
Guest_family: How do you get the risk so low?
We use prophylactic antibiotics to minimize the infection risk.
Guest_family: Will he be able to walk again right after the surgery?
No, he'll need to stay off it for a while, we call this nonweightbearing. It will only be for some time after the procedure, it's not permanent.
Guest_family: What are the rest of the risks?

The total risks of surgery include risks of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, hardware failure, need for other surgical procedures, need to be nonweightbearing for some time. I would not worry about these risks, though. The risk is low.
Guest_family: Okay. Let's do the surgery.

conversations.context: The patient is a pleasant, 31-year-old, right-handed, white female who injured her shoulder while transferring a patient back on 01/01/02.  She formerly worked for Veteran's Home as a CNA.  She has had a long drawn out course of treatment for this shoulder.  She tried physical therapy without benefit and ultimately came to a subacromion decompression in November 2002.  She had ongoing pain and was evaluated by Dr. X who felt that she had a possible brachial plexopathy.  He also felt she had a right superficial radial neuritis and blocked this with resolution of her symptoms.  He then referred her to ABCD who did EMG testing, demonstrating a right suprascapular neuropathy although a C5 radiculopathy could not be ruled out.  MRI testing on the cervical spine was then done which was negative for disk herniation and she underwent suprascapular nerve decompression of the scapular notch on 12/18/03.  She finally went to an anterior axillary nerve block because of ongoing pain in the anterior shoulder again by Dr. X.  She comes to me for impairment rating.  She has no chronic health problems otherwise, fevers, chills, or general malaise.  She is not working.  She is right-hand dominant.  She denies any prior history of injury to her shoulder.

dialogue.message: Welcome back to the clinic.
Thank you.
I understand that we are doing an impairment rating exam today.
Yes, that's correct.
And we are evaluating your right shoulder injury. Correct?
Yes.
Was this a workrelated injury?
Yes. I was working as a C N A at the Veteran's House.
How did the work injury happen?
I was transferring a patient from a wheal chair to a bed, and I hurt my shoulder.
What is the date of the incident?
January first, two thousand and two.
Are you currently working?
No. I have not been able to go back to work yet.
I am required to ask some specific questions for the L and I paperwork. What is your ago, ethnicity and gender?
I am a thirty one year old, white, female.
Have you ever had a prior injury to your right shoulder?
No.
Are right or left hand dominant?
Right.
Other then your shoulder injury, do you have any other chronic health problems?
No.
Are you experiencing any fever, chills or illnesses?
No.
Let discuss some of the previous treatments and test that you have been done for your shoulder.
Okey. I have done a lot of different treatments.
What treatments have you done?
I tried physical therapy. They did a subacromion decompression treatment in November, two thousand and two.
Did either of those treatments help?
Not much. I went and saw Doctor Lin and he said that I might have a nerve fiber injury. I forget what he called it.
Brachial plexopathy?
Yes. That sounds right.

Oh, I see his notes in your chart. It says that he felt like you had a right superficial radial neuritis and blocked this with resolution of your symptoms. Then it looks like he sent you to get E M G testing at Valley Medical. Let me look for those results.
Okey. They should be in my chart. I had Doctor Lin send over all my records.

Here it is. It says that the right suprascapular neuropathy although a C5 radiculopathy could not be ruled out.  MRI testing on the cervical spine was then done which was negative for disk herniation and underwent suprascapular nerve decompression of the scapular notch on December eighteenth, two thousand and three.
Whatever that means? I ended up getting a nerve block because I was still in pain. Doctor Lin did one in the frount of my shoulder and then another in the back.
This has been a long drawn out course of treatments for you.
Yes, it has been.

conversations.context: The patient presents today for followup, history of erectile dysfunction, last visit started on Cialis 10 mg.  He indicates that he has noticed some mild improvement of his symptoms, with no side effect.  On this dose, he is having firm erection, able to penetrate, lasting for about 10 or so minutes.  No chest pain, no nitroglycerin usage, no fever, no chills.  No dysuria, gross hematuria, fever, chills.  Daytime frequency every three hours, nocturia times 0, good stream.  He does have a history of elevated PSA and biopsy June of this year was noted for high grade PIN, mid left biopsy, with two specimens being too small to evaluate.  PSA 11.6.  Dr. X's notes are reviewed.

dialogue.message: How have you been handing erectile dysfunction since your last visit, sir?
Well, I've been taking the Cialis, it's the, um, ten M G version.
Have you seen any improvement?
Yes, I've had some, which is good.
Have you had any side effects?
No, none yet.
Good, can you describe your erections for me, sir?
Well, they're firm now, and I can penetrate again for about ten minutes.
Good, are you having any chest pain?
No sir, I stopped using my nitroglycerin too.
Good, are you having any fever or chills?
No, nothing like that.
Are you having any pain with urination, or blood in the urine?
No, nothing like that, sir, everything is normal.
How often do you urinate during the day?
I go about every three hours or so, I have a good stream and everything.
Do you wake up at night to go to the bathroom?
No, I sleep through the night very well.
Good, do you have any other conditions that I should know about?
Well, I have a history of elevated P S A, and I had a biopsy in June when I had a, um, high grade P I N.
Do you know what that P S A value was?
It was eleven point six.
Thank you, I see here on Doctor X's notes that there were two specimens that were too small to evaluate.

conversations.context: She has had a fairly extensive past medical history but is a somewhat poor historian and is unable to provide details about her history.  She states that she has underlying history of heart disease but is not able to elaborate to any significant extent.  She also has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes but is not currently taking any medication.  She has also had a history of pulmonary embolism approximately four years ago, hyperlipidemia, peptic ulcer disease, and recurrent urinary tract infections.  Surgeries include an appendectomy, cesarean section, cataracts, and hernia repair.

dialogue.message: Have you ever had any heart problems in the past?
I remember I did have something heart related but I don't know what that was. I do not understand any medical terms.
Okay that's fine, I completely understand. We will try to look for your  past medical history.
I do have hypertension and diabetes, you know that right?
Yes, type two diabetes. Do you know of any other things that you had in the past?
Yes, four years back I had lung embolism. I also get frequent urine infections.
Okay. And I can see on the file that you have high cholesterol and a gastric ulcer too.
Yes, that's about right.
Okay. What surgeries have you had in the past?
I have had my appendix taken out, then C Section, cataract surgery and hernia repair done in the past.

conversations.context: 69-year-old Caucasian male complaining of difficulty breathing for 3 days.  He also states that he has been coughing accompanying with low-grade type fever.  He also admits to having intermittent headaches and bilateral chest pain that does not radiate to upper extremities and jaws but worse with coughing.  Patient initially had this type of episodes about 10 months ago but has intermittently getting worse since.

dialogue.message: I see here that you've been feeling more short of breath.
Yes, for three days now.
Is it worse when you exert yourself?
Um no, not really. I've had a terrible cough along with frequent headaches and chest congestion. I have also had a low fever.
Did these symptoms start around the same time?
I think so.
Where does your chest feel most congested? And how would you rate the pain right now? Ten being the worst.
Both sides. I'd say it's at a three currently.
Does it send pain or numbness or tingling down your arms? How about any jaw pain as a result?
No, but it does get worse whenever I cough.
Is this your first time experiencing this type of congestion?
Oh no. I had something like it about ten months ago.
Did that improve on its own?
