It would come and go, but over the past few days it's gotten worse. I am a strong German man so I held out coming to the doctor as long as I could.
You are very strong! You are sixty nine though, so I don't think anyone would see it as weak if you came to the doctor more often.

conversations.context: The patient initially presented with loud obnoxious snoring that disrupted the sleep of his bed partner.  He was found to have moderate-to-severe sleep apnea (predominantly hypopnea), was treated with nasal CPAP at 10 cm H2O nasal pressure.  He has been on CPAP now for several months, and returns for followup to review his response to treatment. The patient reports that the CPAP has limited his snoring at night.  Occasionally, his bed partner wakes him in the middle of the night, when the mask comes off, and reminds him to replace the mask.  The patient estimates that he uses the CPAP approximately 5 to 7 nights per week, and on occasion takes it off and does not replace the mask when he awakens spontaneously in the middle of the night. The patient's sleep pattern consists of going to bed between 11:00 and 11:30 at night and awakening between 6 to 7 a.m. on weekdays.  On weekends, he might sleep until 8 to 9 a.m.  On Saturday night, he might go to bed approximately mid night. As noted, the patient is not snoring on CPAP.  He denies much tossing and turning and does not awaken with the sheets in disarray.  He awakens feeling relatively refreshed. In the past few months, the patient has lost between 15 and 18 pounds in combination of dietary and exercise measures. He continues to work at Smith Barney in downtown Baltimore.  He generally works from 8 to 8:30 a.m. until approximately 5 to 5:30 p.m.  He is involved in training purpose to how to sell managed funds and accounts. The patient reports no change in daytime stamina.  He has no difficulty staying awake during the daytime or evening hours. The past medical history is notable for allergic rhinitis.

dialogue.message: Hello, sir how can I help you? Looks like we are talking about snoring today.
Yeah, I need to get this loud and obnoxious snoring under control. I keep waking up my partner. I have a C P A P right now because I was told I have almost severe sleep apnea.
Yes, I see on your chart that you were given ten centimeters of H two O nasal pressure and that you predominately suffer from hypopnea. Hypopnea is shallow breathing. How has the device been working?

It definitely has reduced my snoring, but my partner keeps waking me up in the middle of the night because the mask pops off. I wear it around five to seven nights a week, but for some reason it falls off or I take it off randomly in the night. My wife usually must remind me to put it back on.
So what is your sleep pattern now? When do you usually go to bed and wake up?

Usually I sleep around eleven or eleven thirty and wake up at six or seven on the weekends. I'll sleep in until eight or nine on the weekdays. On Saturday's I might go to sleep around midnight because I usually watch a show with my family. I feel good when I wake up though. Much less tossing and turning. The sheets are always on the bed still.
That's some good news. I see you have lost a bit of weight too. Around fifteen to eighteen pounds is something to be proud of.
Thanks. It has been a lot of exercising and dieting. I am motivated because I want to stop snoring.
How has work been? Do you think it has been stressful at all?

I still work at Smith Barney in downtown Baltimore. I work from around eight or eight thirty to five or five thirty. I deal with training on how to sell managed funds and accounts. I do not think I have been stressed because I am able to stay awake through my shift and even when I come home at night. I may get a little tired during hay fever season, but that is rare.
Yes, I see that you have hay fever. Fatigue is a common symptom from the allergy.

conversations.context: The patient is a 14-year-old male who reported having knee pain for 1 month.  Apparently while he was playing basketball on 12/22/2007 when he had gone up for a jump, he felt a pop in his knee.  The patient was seen at an outside facility where he was splinted and subsequently referred to Children's for definitive care.  Radiographs confirmed comminuted tibial tubercle avulsion fracture with patella alta.  Surgery is recommended to the grandmother and subsequently to the father by phone.  Surgery would consist of open reduction and internal fixation with subsequent need for later hardware removal.  Risks of surgery include the risks of  anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes on sensation in most of the extremity, hardware failure, need for later hardware removal, failure to restore extensor mechanism tension, and need for postoperative rehab.  All questions were answered, and father and grandmother agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Good morning, young man.
Good morning, doctor.
Who is this young lady, is this your grandmother, or sister?
Guest_family: Oh doctor, yes, I am his grandmother.
Good, my chart says that you're fourteen years old. Is that correct?
Yes sir.
Good, so what seems to be the problem today?
I've been having pain in this knee for about a month now.
Can you remember a specific injury to this knee?
Um, yeah, I was playing basketball when I jumped, and then when I landed I felt this knee pop.
Do you remember the date of your injury, young man?
Guest_family: Um, it was on December twenty second two thousand seven.
Good, so how have you been treated for this so far?
We went to another clinic first, and they put me in a splint.
Guest_family: Yeah, and then they referred us over to Children's.
Have they taken x rays yet?
Yes, I got back a few minutes ago.
Let's have a look. Well, you broke your leg.
What, where? Can you show me?
Right here, this is a tibial tubercule avulsion fracture with patella alta.
Guest_family: What does that mean, doctor?
Well, he's broken his leg, and pulled some bone off by doing so. We'll need to do surgery on this.
Guest_family: Oh no, what's the name of the procedure?
It's called an O R I F. We'll go in there with some hardware to put everything back together, and he can get on the road to healing.
Guest_family: Let me call his father while we discuss this. What's the risk of infection from this surgery?
Historically, it's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.
Guest_family: Okay, will he be asleep for this?
Yes, he won't feel a thing.
Guest_family: That's good too. Will he need this hardware out in the future?

We can remove everything once he has healed up nicely. Other risks include bleeding, changes in the sensation of the leg, hardware failure, need for post op rehab, need for hardware removal, and failure to restore extensor mechanism tension. But I would not worry about these things. I have been doing these surgeries for years and things like this rarely happen.
Guest_family: Yes, his father agrees. We're going to do the surgery.

conversations.context: The patient is an 83-year-old lady, a resident of a skilled nursing facility, with past medical history of a stroke and dementia with expressive aphasia, was found today with a right-sided facial droop, and was transferred to the emergency room for further evaluation.  While in the emergency room, she was found to having the right-sided upper extremity weakness and right-sided facial droop.  The CT scan of the head did not show any acute events with the impression of a new-onset cerebrovascular accident, will be admitted to monitor bed for observation and treatment and also she was recently diagnosed with urinary tract infection, which was resistant to all oral medications.

dialogue.message: Hi there, what's going on?

Guest_family: I am her daughter. I brought her to the emergency. She lives in a skilled nursing home. Today, when I went to meet her, I found her with the right side of her face drooping. I immediately rushed her here.
Oh, you did the right thing. Ma'am, how are you feeling?
Guest_family: She has dementia, most of the time she doesn't even remember me.
Oh, okay.How old is she?
Guest_family: She is eighty three. She also has a history of stroke after which she developed this condition where she knows what she wants to speak but is unable to make the word or sentence.
Oh, I see. She has expressive aphasia, correct?
Guest_family: Yes, that.
Okay, let me check her. She does have a droop to her right side of the face. Ma'am, do you feel any weakness on the right side of your body?
Guest_family: She says yes.
She had her C T scan earlier today and I have the report. It does not show any acute attack or anything.
Guest_family: Okay!
But it does show that she has a new onset of a stroke.
Guest_family: Is there anything to worry?

I think we need to admit her for observation. We need to monitor her. We will also get her a proper treatment for her urinary infection which is not getting better due to resistance to the oral medicines.
Guest_family: Yeah, sounds good!
Yeah, let me talk to the nurse.
Guest_family: Thank you.

conversations.context: This patient presents to the office today because he has not been feeling well.  He was in for a complete physical on 05/02/2008.  According to the chart, the patient gives a history of feeling bad for about two weeks.  At first he thought it was stress and anxiety and then he became worried it was something else.  He says he is having a lot of palpitations. He gets a fluttering feeling in his chest.  He has been very tired over two weeks as well.  His job has been really getting to him.  He has been feeling nervous and anxious.  It seems like when he is feeling stressed he has more palpitations, sometimes they cause chest pain.  These symptoms are not triggered by exertion.  He had similar symptoms about 9 or 10 years ago.  At that time he went through a full workup.  Everything ended up being negative and they gave him something that he took for his nerves and he says that helped.  Unfortunately, he does not remember what it was.  Also over the last three days he has had some intestinal problems.  He has had some intermittent nausea and his stools have been loose.  He has been having some really funny green color to his bowel movements.  There has been no blood in the stool.  He is not having any abdominal pain, just some nausea.  He does not have much of an appetite.  He is a nonsmoker.

dialogue.message: Hello there, how are you doing?
Sorry, I'm just not feeling well. Something is wrong.
Don't worry, I will check you up. We will figure it out. Do you remember when you had your last physical?
It was sometime in early May in two thousand and eight.
Okay, I'm going through your chart. It looks like you have not been feeling well for about two weeks now.
That's right.
Tell me what is happening exactly.
In the beginning I was thinking that it was just the stress and anxiety, but then I become worried that it might be something really different or something bad.
What are you experiencing exactly? What are your symptoms?
It started with a lot of palpitations at first. My heart was beating so fast it looks like it was ready to go out. I was having this fluttering feeling in my chest.
Were you feeling tired or fatigued?
Yes, very much for the last two weeks. I am worried it's my job. It is really getting to me.
What else are you feeling?
Feeling very nervous an anxious actually.
Have you noticed anything that you are doing or anything else that kind of increasing these symptoms?
Oh yeah, whenever I'm stressed. I feel like I have more palpitations and to the level that it causes a lot of chest pain.
Is it the same when you are doing a lot of physical stuff like physical activities or something like that?
Nope. Haven't noticed it with the exertion part.
Do you have any history of any heart issues in the past?
I had the same kind of symptoms like nine or ten years ago.
Okay. What did you do that time? How did you recover?
Well, at that time a full work up was done but everything came out to be negative, so they just gave me something for my nerves. It kind of helped.
Do you remember what they gave you? Like name or anything of the medicine.
No. It was many years ago, I don't remember.
Anything else going on?
Yeah, for the last three days and I am having these tummy issues. I'm having on and off nausea and also, my stools are coming loose.
Have you seen any color change in your bowel movements?
Yeah, it's been some really funny green color. I don't know what's going on inside.
Have you ever noticed blood in the stools?
Nope.
Is there any pain in your tummy?
Nope, it's just some nausea.
How's your appetite?
Not as good as before.
Do you smoke?
I never did.

conversations.context: He said he has had two surgeries in 07/06 followed by radiation and then again in 08/07.  He then had a problem with seizures, hemiparesis, has been to the hospital, developed C-diff, and is in the nursing home currently.  He is unable to stand at the moment.  He is unable to care for himself.  I reviewed the information that was sent down with him from the nursing home which includes his medical history.

dialogue.message: How are you feeling today, sir?
I feel pretty weak right now, but I am doing okay at the moment.
I reviewed the chart notes that was sent to me by the nursing home. They also sent me your medical history. You have been going through a lot recently.
Yes, I have. They moved me into the nursing home after I was released from the hospital. I hope that it is just temporary.
I understand that you had a seizer and that is why you were taken to the hospital.
I had multiple seizures. After I was stabilized from the last seizure this side of my body in not working right.
Okay so you are having some partial weakness on this side?
Yes. That is why they moved me to the nursing home. I can't stand up. I am too weak. I can't take care of myself. The nurses have to help me do everything.
I am going to try to help you get back to doing things on your own.
After being in the hospital I got an infection in my intestines. They put me on some antibiotic that I have never heard of and a probiotic.
Okay. I see here in the chart that you had two surgeries on July sixth.
Yes, and then I had a radiation treatment too.
Oh yes. On August seventh.
That sounds right.
Your surgeries may have been the reason for the C diff.
What is C diff?

It is an infection in the large intestine. It is often caused by overuse of antibiotics, and you have been on them for a while due to the surgeries that you have had. Or it could be from the surgery itself.
That make since.

conversations.context: No rashes, headache, photophobia, diplopia, or oral ulcers. No palpitations, orthopnea or PND. No diarrhea, constipation, melena, bright red blood per rectum, or pale stool. No jaundice. Decreased appetite, but no weight loss.

dialogue.message: Just want to ask you few routine questions, let me know if any of this is positive.
Sure, go ahead.
Do you have any problems like headache, fever, rash, oral ulcer?
None.
Any problem with vision? Like unable to see or double vision?
Um no, I can see everything.
Okay. Do you get palpitations, like are you aware of your own heart?
No, nothing like that.
How about breathlessness while lying down or do you have to get up in the middle of the night to catch a breath?
No I don't feel anything like that.
That's great. Any diarrhea, constipation, or red blood come out in stool? Or pale stool? Like any change in the color of stool?
No, it is fine.
Okay. Any jaundice recently?
No. No jaundice.
Do you have problems with appetite?
Yeah, I mean you can say my appetite is decreased.
Because of that have you noticed any weight loss?
Oh no.
Okay sounds good.
Sure.

conversations.context: This is a 50-year-old male who presented to ABCD General Hospital Emergency Department with complaints of left ankle pain and disfigurement.  There was no open injury.  The patient fell approximately 10 feet off his liner, landing on his left foot.  There was evidence of gross deformity of the ankle.  An x-ray was performed in the Emergency Room, which revealed a grade IV Hawkins classification talus fracture.  He was distal neurovascularly intact.  The patient denied any other complaints besides pain in the ankle. It was for this reason, we elected to undergo the  procedure in order to reduce and restore the blood supply to the talus body.  Because of its tenuous blood supply, the patient is at risk for avascular necrosis.  The patient has agreed to undergo the above-named procedure and consent was obtained.  All risks as well as complications were discussed.

dialogue.message: Good evening, and welcome to A B C D General Hospital E D.
Thank you, Doctor, I've really messed up this ankle.
Before we begin, how old are you? And which gender do you identify?
Thank you for asking, Doctor, I'm a fifty year old man.
Thank you, what happened?
I fell off my liner, and I landed right onto my left foot.
How far did you fall?
Um, it was really about ten feet.
Oh, yes, I see. I have some good news for you, there's no gross deformity in this ankle.
What does that mean, exactly?
I don't see any ankle dislocation, which is good.
Oh, that's good news.
Have you had your x rays taken yet?
Yeah, the tech just brought me back.
Great, let me pull them up here. Okay, um, if you look here, you'll see a fracture of your talus.
Which bone is that?
That's your heel, to be specific, it's a grade I V Hawkins fracture of the left talus. You are still neurovascularly intact in the distal region.
What are we going to do about this?
Do you have any other pain from the fall, aside from the ankle?
No, the ankle really took all of the weight of the fall.
Okay, I think we should do surgery in order to repair this ankle.
Why is that?
There is very weak blood flow to the body of this bone, there's a risk for avascular necrosis, which is bone death.
Okay, you're right. What are the risks of this infection with this surgery?
Overall, the risks of infection are less than one percent. We'll use antibiotics to keep everything clean.
Will I be asleep for this?
Yes, you'll be under anesthesia.
Okay, yes, um, I'd like to go forward with the surgery.

conversations.context: This is a 58-year-old male who started out having toothache in the left lower side of the mouth that is now radiating into his jaw and towards his left ear.  Triage nurse reported that he does not believe it is his tooth because he has regular dental appointments, but has not seen a dentist since this new toothache began.  The patient denies any facial swelling.  No headache.  No swelling to the throat.  No sore throat.  No difficulty swallowing liquids or solids.  No neck pain.  No lymph node swelling.  The patient denies any fever or chills.  Denies any other problems or complaints.

dialogue.message: What's bringing you in today?
I've had a terrible toothache. I can't stand the pain anymore. I have never experienced this pain in fifty eight years.
Where are you experiencing the most pain? And when did this pain start?
It started about three weeks ago. It's mostly on the left side of my mouth. Kind of on the lower end. It goes from my jaw all the way up to my left ear.
That doesn't sound the least bit comfortable. Let's get you feeling better. Do you think it's related to your tooth?
No, I don't think so. I'm pretty good at making my dentist appointments, although I haven't been in since this new pain started.
I see. When was the last time you visited the dentist?
About two months ago for a routine clean.
Have you noticed any facial swelling since all of this started?
No, no swelling.
Any headaches, throat swelling, sore throat, difficulty swallowing or chewing?
No.
How about any neck pain, swollen lymph nodes, chills, fever, or other symptoms?
No, thank goodness.

conversations.context: This is a 15-year-old girl presenting with occipital headache for the last six hours.  She denies trauma.  She has been intermittently nauseated but has not vomited and has some photophobia.  Denies fever or change in vision.  She has no past history of headaches.

dialogue.message: Hello, I am Doctor James.
Guest_family: Hi Doctor, this is my daughter Miya, and I am Jena.
Nice to meet you ladies. So, Miya how old are you?
I am fifteen.
Okay, so tell me what is going on with you?
Well, I am having a severe headache.
Guest_family: She has been complaining about it for almost six hours now.
Oh wow. Can you tell me where exactly the pain is?
Um, it started from my neck and then moved up to the back of my head.
I see. Did you get hurt or bump your head?
No.
Does she have any history of headaches?
Guest_family: No.
Okay, any nausea or vomiting?
I am having nausea, but it's coming and going but no vomiting. Also, I am not able to tolerate light at all.
Hm, are you able to see properly though, any change in your vision?
No.
Any fever?
No.
Guest_family: No, no fever.
Okay.

conversations.context: This is a 69-year-old male with complaints of bilateral knee pain for several years and increased intensity in the past several months where it has affected his activities of daily living.  He attempted conservative treatment, which includes anti-inflammatory medications as well as cortisone and Synvisc.  This has only provided him with temporary relief.  It is for that reason, he is elected to undergo the above-named procedure. All risks as well as complications were discussed with the patient, which include, but are not limited to infection, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, need for further surgery, and further pain.  He has agreed to undergo this procedure and a consent was obtained preoperatively.

dialogue.message: Good afternoon, doctor.
Remind me, please, how old are you?
I'm sixty nine years old, doctor.
Thank you, what seems to be the problem today?
Oh, I've had pain in these knees for years, but it's been getting a lot worse over the last few months.
Is the pain messing with your ability to do activities?
Absolutely, sir, yes it is.
What kind of treatments have you had so far?
Another doctor called it conservative treatment, um, I've taken antiinflammatories and had some injections.
Do you remember what kind of injections you've had?
It was, um, cortisone, and Synvisc.
Did these relieve the pain at all?
Well, it was only a temporary relief. Is there anything else we can do?
Well, there is surgery for this.
What are the risks of infection from the surgery?
Historically, it's less than one percent.
How is this possible?
We use prophylactic antibiotics in order to eliminate the risk.
That's great, I've heard of D V T from the commercials, is there a risk for that?
There's a risk, but it's low. Other risks are pulmonary embolism, need for further surgery, and further pain.
Okay, yes, I'd like to do the surgery.

conversations.context: Mom brings the patient in today for possible ear infection.  He is complaining of left ear pain today.  He was treated on 04/14/2004, with amoxicillin for left otitis and Mom said he did seem to get better but just started complaining of the left ear pain today.  He has not had any fever but the congestion has continued to be very thick and purulent.  It has never really resolved.  He has a loose, productive-sounding cough but not consistently and not keeping him up at night.  No wheezing or shortness of breath.

dialogue.message: How's this little guy doing today?
Guest_family: I think he might have another ear infection.
Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. Let's have a look see.
Guest_family: He's been telling me over and over again that his left ear is hurting him. He was here on April fourteenth and prescribed Amoxicillin.
Did that seem to help?
Guest_family: It did at first, but the pain is back again.
Has he been running any fevers?
Guest_family: No, no fevers.
He sounds a bit congested.
Guest_family: He is. When he blows his nose, he brings up really thick mucous. This never really went away even with antibiotics. He's also been coughing a fair amount.
Is his cough productive?
Guest_family: Yeah.
Does it seem to be keeping him up at night? How does the mucous look?
Guest_family: No, I don't think so. It is pretty thick and viscous. The cough isn't constant or anything.
And no shortness of breath or wheezing that you've noticed?
Guest_family: No.

conversations.context: This is the initial clinic visit for a 41-year-old worker who is seen for a foreign body to his left eye.  He states that he was doing his normal job when he felt a foreign body sensation.  He attempted to flush this at work, but has had persistent pain which has progressively worsened throughout the course of the day.  He has no significant blurriness of vision or photophobia.

dialogue.message: So it looks like you're here today for a noticeable foreign body sensation in your eye.
Yeah, my left eye. Never had this happen to me in my forty one years.
First time for everything I guess! When did you first notice the sensation?

Um when I was at work this morning. It felt like something was in my eye. I went to the bathroom mirror to check it out, but didn't see anything. I flushed my eyes with water in hopes of it helping with the weird feeling.
Okay. Hm, are you experiencing any eye pain, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light?
The pain has definitely gotten worse since this morning. My vision is fine and bright lights don't seem to be a problem.

conversations.context: 1.  Infection. 2.  Pelvic pain. 3.  Mood swings. 4.  Painful sex.

dialogue.message: What brings you in today?
I've had a lot of discomfort in my private area.
When did it start?
It's been going on for about two weeks now.
Have you noticed any abnormal discharge?
Not really, no. But it's been super itchy down there.
Any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting?
Uh no, but I'm having some pain here.
Near your pelvis?
Yeah.
Have you started any new lotions or products?
No.
Have you tried anything for the pain or itching?
No, not yet. I thought it'd go away on it's own.
If it's okay with you, I'd like to do a pelvic exam.
Fine with me.
Have you been sexually active prior to or after noticing these concerns?
Uh once this past week, but it was pretty painful.
I see. You may have an infection, which is why I'd also like to send out samples to the lab. Did you use protection?
Yeah, I take birth control. But I've been struggling a bit with my mood and I'm wondering if it's because of the new birth control pills.
We can look into that as well. Hang tight while I grab the nurse for the pelvic exam.

conversations.context: Otherwise well.  No febrile illness.  No motor or sensory complaints of any sort or paresthesias in the hand.

dialogue.message: So how are you feeling?
I am feeling well.
Any illness or fever?
No, nothing like that.
Any headache or nausea?
No.
Any vomiting or stomach upset?
No.
Okay, any numbness tingling or loss of sensation in the hand?
No, not at all.
Otherwise feeling well?
Yeah.

conversations.context: The patient is a pleasant but demented 80-year-old male, who lives in board and care, who presented with acute onset of abdominal pain.  In the emergency room, the patient was found to have a CT scan with dilated bladder with thick wall suggesting an outlet obstruction as well as bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter.  The patient is unable to provide further history.  The patient's son is at the bedside and confirmed his history.  The patient was given IV antibiotics in the emergency room.  He was also given some hydration.

dialogue.message: Hello, how are you?
What?
How are you related to the patient?
Guest_family: Hello doctor, I am his son.
Hello. How old is he?
Guest_family: He is eighty years old. He is suffering from dementia.
I see. Do you think he will be able to provide me with his medical history?
Guest_family: I don't think so. Sometimes he even forgets his name.
He's kidding. I know my name. I also know his kids' names. I do agree that sometimes I forget my things or feel lost.
I don't blame you. I forget my things at my age.
Guest_family: Yeah, it is something like episodic that he forgets everything and sometimes he's absolutely normal. On good days, he's very nice to talk to.
What is his living status?
Guest_family: He lives at a board and care. It is a cozier homelike place.
That's good. So what brings you here in the emergency today?

Guest_family: He started complaining of stomach aches. Luckily, I was there. It was very sudden at one moment he was talking to me nicely and then all of a sudden he started complaining of severe pain in his stomach area. That's when I decided to bring him here in the emergency room.
Do you have any previous reports?
I have these reports.
Do you remember when was this scan done?
I have no idea. I just had these reports with me.
Do you remember of any medical issues before?
Huh uh.

Okay, let me see what your scan says. I am reading the C T Scan report provided by the patient. It states that patient has dilated bladder with thick wall suggesting an outlet obstruction as well as bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter.
Hm.
I see that you have already been given some I V fluid along with antibiotics by the emergency room doctor.
Guest_family: Yeah.
Did he ever complain of pain during urination or nausea and vomiting?

Guest_family: Yes, he had fever a few days back. When we asked him about other symptoms, he said, it's hard to urinate and it is painful. Nausea and vomiting are something that I am not sure about. He was normally rushing to the restroom and every time used to say he didn't want to pee as it hurt him. He also had a few accidents in the last few days where he wet himself.
Thank you for providing me with all his history. It will be very helpful for me to treat him now.

conversations.context: Chest pain and fever.

dialogue.message: Hey, what's going on with you today?
Oh, I have a chest pain.
You have fever too?
Yes, I did.

conversations.context: This is a 39-year-old female who has sustained a twisting injury to her knee while on trampoline in late August.  She was diagnosed per MRI.  An MRI confirmed the clinical diagnosis of anterior cruciate ligament tear.  She states she has had multiple episodes of instability to the patellofemoral joint throughout the years with multiple dislocations.  She elected to proceed with surgery to repair the anterior cruciate ligament as well as possibly plicate the medial retinaculum to help prevent further dislocations of the patellofemoral joint.  All risks and benefits of surgery were discussed with her at length.  She was in agreement with the treatment plan.

dialogue.message: Good morning, ma'am. My nurses tell me that you're thirty nine years old, is that correct?
Good morning, Doctor. Yes, that's correct.
So, what seems to be the problem today, ma'am?
I hurt my knee while on the trampoline back in late August.
Do you remember the mechanism of injury to this knee?
What do you mean?
Well, was it a twisting, pulling, snapping kind of injury?
Oh, I twisted my knee.
Okay, have you seen another doctor for this?
Yeah, and I got an M R I.
Can I see the report?
Yes, here you go.
This M R I shows an A C L tear. Do you have any instability in this knee?
Yeah, I feel like my knee joint has been unstable for years.
Have there been any dislocations?
Yeah, there have been. What can be done about this?
Well, there's surgery to fix this. I can repair that A C L.
What are the risks of infection with the procedure?
Historically, it's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.
Will I go under for this?
Yes, you won't feel a thing.
Okay, yes, I'd like the surgery done.

conversations.context: Mr. ABC is a 2-year-old boy, who is brought in by parents, stating that the child keeps complaining of belly and back pain.  This does not seem to be slowing him down.  They have not noticed any change in his urine or bowels.  They have not noted him to have any fevers or chills or any other illness.  They state he is otherwise acting normally.  He is eating and drinking well.  He has not had any other acute complaints, although they have noted a foul odor coming from his nose.  Apparently, he was seen here a few weeks ago for a foreign body in the right nose, which was apparently a piece of cotton; this was removed and placed on antibiotics.  His nose got better and then started to become malodorous again.  Mother restarted him on the remainder of the antibiotics and they are also stating that they think there is something still in there.  Otherwise, he has not had any runny nose, earache, no sore throat.  He has not had any cough, congestion.  He has been acting normally.  Eating and drinking okay.  No other significant complaints.  He has not had any pain with bowel movement or urination, nor have they noted him to be more frequently urinating, then again he is still on a diaper.

dialogue.message: Hello! Who do we have here today?
Guest_family: Hello, this is our son, A B C.
How old is he? What is the issue?
Guest_family: He is two. He is continuously complaining of pain in his belly and back. He is active otherwise.
Did you notice any change in his toilet habits or routine?
Guest_family: No.
Any fever or chills or any other issue?
Guest_family: No, we did not notice any such issues, he has been active and was acting very normal otherwise.
Any change in his eating habits?

Guest_family: No, he has been eating and drinking as usual. He was acting normally but we did notice a foul odor coming from his nose. He was on antibiotics after removal of that piece of cotton from his right side of nose in our previous visit here.
How is his nose now?
Guest_family: He got better but now we can notice that odor from his nose again.
Guest_family: His mother started him on the antibiotics again, whatever was remaining, we think something is still there.
Okay, Is there anything else like runny nose or any pain in his ear or bad throat? How about cough or congestion? Or any other issues you have noticed?
Guest_family: No, nothing of those instead he has been active and eating and drinking normally, no other issue.
Is he complaining of any pain or discomfort on bowel movements? Is there any increase in the frequency of urination?
Guest_family: Well, we can't say it for sure as he still wears diapers but we have not noticed anything abnormal.

conversations.context: The patient is a 12-year-old boy born at a 32-week gestation and with drug exposure in utero.  The patient has diagnosis of autism as well.  The patient presented with bilateral knee flexion contractures, initially worse on right than left.  He had right distal medial hamstring release performed in February 2007 and has done quite well and has noted significant improvement in his gait and his ability to play.  The patient presents now with worsening left knee flexion contracture, and desires the same procedure to be performed.  Risks and benefits of the surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of extremity, failure to restore normal anatomy, continued contracture, possible need for other procedures.  All questions were answered and mother and son agreed to above plan.

dialogue.message: Please, tell me a little more about your son.
Guest_family: Well, he's twelve years old now, but he was born at about a month and a half early.
Were there any other complications with the pregnancy?
Guest_family: He was exposed to drugs in the womb while I was pregnant, and he has been diagnosed with autism.
Okay. I see he has previously had an operation on the right knee, can you tell me more about that?
Guest_family: He previously had a lot of trouble straightening out both of his legs, and since the right was worse than the left he had an operation on the inside part of the back of that leg.
When was this operation?
Guest_family: It was in February of two thousand seven.
How did he respond to the operation?
Guest_family: He responded really well, he was walking much better, and even got back to playing sports with the other kids in the neighborhood.
What seems to be the problem today?
Guest_family: Now, his left knee is getting really bad, it's like how the right knee was. He can't straighten this leg. I think we should do the same operation again on the left knee.
Yes, I think we'll have to do surgery.
Guest_family: What is the risk of infection with the surgery?
Historically, it's been less than one percent, we use prophylactic antibiotics in order to minimize infection risk.
Guest_family: Will he be under anesthesia for the procedure?
Yes, he will be. He won't feel anything.
Guest_family: Will this completely solve his problem?

I can't guarantee that he won't need additional procedures in the future. The other risks include, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion to the leg, failure to restore normal anatomy, and risk it won't work in general.
Guest_family: What's the name of this procedure?
It's called a distal medial hamstring release.
Guest_family: This is the same procedure he had in two thousand seven, right?
Yes ma'am, the exact same one.
Guest_family: Okay, that sounds good, we want to go through with the procedure.
Okay, here is my surgical scheduler's business card, give them a call, and they can walk you through everything.

conversations.context: Dyspnea on exertion.  No chest pain or tightness, fever, chills, sweats, cough, hemoptysis, or wheeze, or lower extremity swelling.

dialogue.message: Oh doc, I've had a lot of trouble breathing lately.
I'm sorry to hear that. We'll get to the bottom of it.
Yeah, I lose my breath so quickly with just one to two flights of stairs.
When did you first start noticing this?
I believe two weeks ago.
Any chest pain or tightness with the shortness of breath?
No, thankfully.
Any fever, chills, or sweats?
No.
Any cough or coughing up blood?
No.
How about wheezing or swelling in your legs?
No.

conversations.context: The patient is a 13-year-old right-hand dominant girl, who fell off a swing at school around 1:30 today.  The patient was initially seen at an outside facility and brought here by her father, given findings on x-ray, a closed reduction was attempted on the left elbow.  After the attempted reduction, the patient was noted to have an incarcerated medial epicondyle fracture as well as increasing ulnar paresthesias that were not present prior to the procedure.  Given this finding, the patient needed urgent open reduction and internal fixation to relieve the pressure on the ulnar nerve.  At that same time, the patient's mildly angulated radial shaft fracture will be reduced.  This was explained to the father.  The risks of surgery included the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, hardware failure, need for later hardware removal, and possible continuous nerve symptoms.  All questions were answered.  The father agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Good afternoon, who's the victim today, sir? Is it you, or your daughter?
Guest_family: Good afternoon, doctor. It's my daughter today.
Remind me, how old is she?
I'm thirteen, sir.
So, what happened? My nurses tell me she fell today.
Yeah, I fell off the swing at school earlier this afternoon at about one thirty.
Where does it hurt, young lady?
It's really bad here on my left elbow.
Which hand do you write with?
I use my right hand for everything, thank goodness for that.
Before seeing me, have you seen anyone else?
Guest_family: Yeah, we went to an Urgent Care and she had an x ray there.
What else did they do?
Guest_family: They said her arm was broken, and they tried to do a reduction.
Do you have those x rays with you right now?
Guest_family: Yeah, I have them right here, take a look, please.
Well, these x rays show an incarcerated medial epicondyle fracture, as well as a mildly angulated radial shaft break.
What does that mean?
Well, in short, you broke the inside part of your elbow. In addition to the pain, do you have any burning or tingling feelings in that arm?
Yes, I do.
Did you have this before they tried to do a reduction?
No, I didn't, this is new.
Is this feeling getting worse?
Yes, it is.
Okay, guys, there is a lot of pressure on that ulnar nerve because of the break and the attempted reduction.
Guest_family: What should we do?
We need to do an O R I F procedure A S A P. I'll reduce that radial shaft fracture at the same time.
Guest_family: O R I F? What's that
I'll put some pins in the elbow, in order to stabilize the break, and we can start the healing process.
Guest_family: Will this not heal on its own?
No, we need to do the surgery.
Guest_family: Okay, what are the risks of infection with the surgery?
Historically, its less than one percent.
Guest_family: How is this possible?
We use prophylactic antibiotics, this helps us control for infection the entire time.
Guest_family: Will she be asleep for this?
Yes, she won't feel a thing.
Guest_family: Will she need this hardware taken out in the future?

Yes, in about a year or two, after everything is healed up nicely. The other risks include bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, and hardware failure. I see good results from my surgeries so I would not worry about these things, but I must disclose.
Guest_family: Okay, yes, we'd like to do the surgery.

conversations.context: Mom brings patient in today because of sore throat starting last night.  Eyes have been very puffy.  He has taken some Benadryl when all of this congestion started but with a sudden onset just yesterday.  He has had low-grade fever and just felt very run down, appearing very tired.  He is still eating and drinking well, and his voice has been hoarse but no coughing.  No shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea or abdominal pain.

dialogue.message: Hello. You must be his mom.
Guest_family: Yeah, he started having a sore throat last night. And that's why we are here. His eyes have been really puffy. Uh, we gave him some Benadryl.
Hm.
I had a stuffy nose and it was hard to breathe.
When did it all start?
Guest_family: It started yesterday. All of a sudden, he started complaining saying, â€œMama my nose is not working,â€ and yeah, I noticed he was breathing from his mouth.
Any fever or any other symptoms?
Guest_family: Yeah, he had some low grade fever. He looked very tired and when I asked him he said that, â€œI feel like I cannot stand. I have no energy. I want to just lie down.â€
I can notice that his voice is a little bit hoarse. How's he eating and drinking?
Guest_family: He's eating and drinking normally.
Any shortness of breath or pain in your stomach?
No.
Any diarrhea or vomiting?
No.

conversations.context: MSK: Normal gait and station.  No pathology to digits or nails.  Extremities move times four.  No tenderness or effusion.  Range of motion adequate.  Strength and tone equal bilaterally, stable.

dialogue.message: Any muscular pain?
No, not really.
Any problem in walking?
No, it's normal.
Let me check your toes and fingers. Can you move them for me?
Yeah.
Everything looks fine. Nails looks fine too. No bluish discoloration no sign of any infection. Can you push your legs against my hand.
Both legs?
Yes, both. Well, your muscular strength is equal and stable in both legs, so that's fine. Motion looks adequate.
Any tenderness?
No.
And I don't see any swelling or fluid accumulation.
Okay.

conversations.context: This is a 1-year-old male who comes in with a cough and congestion for the past two to three weeks.  Started off as a congestion but then he started coughing about a week ago.  Cough has gotten worsen.  Mother was also worried.  He had Pop Can just three days ago and she never found the top of that and was wondering if he had swallowed that, but his breathing has not gotten worse since that happened.  He is not running any fevers.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: He is coughing for one week now.
How about any congestion? Is it one week or more?
Guest_family: No did I say that? I meant two to three weeks. I am so worried. He is just one year.
Don't worry let me see, can you tell me everything from the beginning?
Guest_family: Sure. It started off as a congestion, but then he started coughing about a week ago and it is getting worse.
Okay, what else?
Guest_family: Actually, he had Pop Can just three days ago and I never found the top of that and was wondering if he had swallowed that.
It is possible, have you seen any change in his breathing?
Guest_family: His breathing has not gotten worse since that happened.
Any fever?
Guest_family: No. No fever.
Okay.

conversations.context: XYZ is in today not feeling well for the last three days.  She is a bit sick with bodyaches.  She is coughing.  She has a sore throat, especially when she coughs.  Her cough is productive of green colored sputum.  She has had some chills.  No vomiting.  No diarrhea.  She is sleeping okay.  She does not feel like she needs anything for the cough.  She did call in yesterday, and got a refill of her Keflex.  She took two Keflex this morning and she is feeling a little bit better now.  She is tearful, just tired of feeling ran down.

dialogue.message: How are you feeling? You have been sick?
Yes, I am not feeling well for the last three days.  I have bad body aches, cough and a sore throat.
Do you get wet cough or it's dry? What color sputum comes out?
It is wet and green colored stuff comes out.
Okay we will need to send it out to culture, maybe an infection.
How about fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea anything like that? Are you sleeping well?
Everything is fine except some chills? I am sleeping okay.
Do you need anything for cough?
I don't need anything for the cough. I did call yesterday and got a refill of my Keflex. Then I took two Keflex this morning and I am feeling little bit better now.
Okay then why are you crying, ma'am?
I am just tired of feeling like ran down.
I am so sorry.
Hm.

conversations.context: Aciphex 20 mg q.d. and aspirin 81 mg q.d.

dialogue.message: Do you take anything for acid reflux?
Yeah, I take Aciphex.
Is that twenty M G once a day?
It is. I also take one baby Aspirin in the mornings.

conversations.context: A 77-year-old white female who is having more problems with joint pain.  It seems to be all over decreasing her mobility, hands and wrists.  No real swelling but maybe just a little more uncomfortable than they have been.  The Daypro generic does not seem to be helping at all.  No fever or chills.  No erythema. She actually is doing better.  Her diarrhea now has settled down and she is having less urinary incontinence, less pedal edema.  Blood sugars seem to be little better as well. The patient also has gotten back on her Zoloft because she thinks she may be depressed, sleeping all the time, just not herself and really is disturbed that she cannot be more mobile in things.  She has had no polyuria, polydipsia, or other problems.  No recent blood pressure checks.

dialogue.message: How are you feeling?
I've been having a lot more joint pain lately.
You're seventy seven, correct?
Don't remind me.
When did you first start experiencing joint pain?
Couple years ago.
In what ways has it worsened?
It's caused me to become less active in general. My hands and wrists aren't as mobile.
Have you noticed any increased swelling?
No, but it's all gotten to be a little too uncomfortable.
I see here that you take the generic of Daypro. Is that helping?
No.
And no redness to the area, right?
No.
Fever or chills?
I had diarrhea for a few days, but it's gotten much better. I was also having trouble holding my bladder.
Are you going to the bathroom more often, experiencing excessive thirst, or other problems?
No. My incontinence is a bit better and so is my ankle and foot swelling.
How has your blood sugar been?
A little better.
Have you checked your blood pressure recently?
Not recently.
Any new medications?
I'm back on Zoloft again because I think I might be depressed. Ever since losing most of my mobility, I haven't been feeling like my usual myself. I'm also sleeping all the time.

conversations.context: The patient is a 28-year-old, who is status post gastric bypass surgery nearly one year ago.  He has lost about 200 pounds and was otherwise doing well until yesterday evening around 7:00-8:00 when he developed nausea and right upper quadrant pain, which apparently wrapped around toward his right side and back.  He feels like he was on it but has not done so.  He has overall malaise and a low-grade temperature of 100.3.  He denies any prior similar or lesser symptoms.  His last normal bowel movement was yesterday.  He denies any outright chills or blood per rectum.

dialogue.message: So, tell me what's going on with you?
Well, yesterday evening between seven or eight I developed nausea and suddenly it started hurting on the right side of my chest?
Where exactly did it hurt?
Ah, my upper chest part and it went all around my right side till my back.
Okay, how do you feel now?
I feel very weak and tired, don't feel like doing anything but resting.
Any fever?
Yeah, nurse just took my temperature it was one hundred point three.
Okay. Did you have these symptoms before?
No, first time. I never felt like this before.
Okay. Any chills or shivering?
No.
When was your last bowel movement?
It was yesterday.
Did you notice any blood in your stool or any rectum bleeding?
No.
How old are you?
I am twenty eight.
Okay, and you had a gastric bypass surgery, one year ago.
Yes, almost one year ago. I lost about two hundred pounds after that.
And you felt well after the surgery?
Absolutely! Until yesterday when my nausea and pain started.
Okay.

conversations.context: GENERAL: Negative weakness, negative fatigue, native malaise, negative chills, negative fever, negative night sweats, negative allergies.

dialogue.message: I need to ask you a few questions.
Sure.
Do you feel any weakness or tiredness?
No.
Any uneasiness or illness?
No, nothing of that sort.
Any chills or high temperature?
Nope.
Any excessive sweating or night sweating?
Um, no.
How about allergies, are you allergic to anything?
No, no allergies.
Alright.

conversations.context: A 34-year-old male presents today self-referred at the recommendation of Emergency Room physicians and his nephrologist to pursue further allergy evaluation and treatment.  Please refer to chart for history and physical, as well as the medical records regarding his allergic reaction treatment at ABC Medical Center for further details and studies.  In summary, the patient had an acute event of perioral swelling, etiology uncertain, occurring on 05/03/2008 requiring transfer from ABC Medical Center to XYZ Medical Center due to a history of renal failure requiring dialysis and he was admitted and treated and felt that his allergy reaction was to Keflex, which was being used to treat a skin cellulitis dialysis shunt infection.  In summary, the patient states he has some problems with tolerating grass allergies, environmental and inhalant allergies occasionally, but has never had anaphylactic or angioedema reactions.  He currently is not taking any medication for allergies.  He is taking atenolol for blood pressure control.  No further problems have been noted upon his discharge and treatment, which included corticosteroid therapy and antihistamine therapy and monitoring.

dialogue.message: Hello, sir. I see you're being seen for an evaluation for your allergy. Can you please confirm your age?
Yeah, that's right. Thirty four.
Let me take a look at your medical records. I see you were treated at the A B C Medical Center for an allergic reaction, correct?
Yeah. I was rushed to the hospital that day. After, they told me to get checked for a follow up.
Who told you to have a follow up?
One of the E R doctors and the kidney doctor.

I see. Your records indicate you had some swelling around the eye on May third of two thousand and eight. The cause was unknown. I see you were transferred from A B C Medical Center to X Y Z Medical center that day.
Yeah, that sounds about right. Were there more details about that?

Yeah, there is. It says here you have a history of renal failure, so you needed dialysis. They believe the allergic reaction was due to this medicine called, Keflex, which was used during your dialysis treatment. Does that name ring a bell?
Yeah, it does. I forgot why they gave it to me.
Usually, Keflex is used to treat a skin cellulitis dialysis shunt infection.
Oh, I see.
I would like to ask you more about your allergies. What would you say you're allergic to?
I've had a lot of problems with grass and sometimes pollen.
I see. I'll put that down as grass allergies, and environmental and inhalant allergies. Do you have any life-threatening allergic reactions?
Nope. Never had that.
Have you ever had any swelling under the skin due to something you ate or touched?
Nope. Never had that either.
That's great. I'm taking a look at your medications. I see you aren't taking anything for your allergies, but you are taking Atenolol. Do you have high blood pressure?
Yeah, I do.
I see. All that's left from your report are the treatments they gave you before you were discharged from the hospital.
What were the treatments they gave me?
Looks like they monitored you the whole time and gave you some corticosteroid therapy and antihistamine therapy. You didn't have any additional problems as well.

conversations.context: Detox from heroin.

dialogue.message: You do not look so well today. What seems to be the problem?
Wellâ€š I am having a hard time. My whole body aches and I am in pain.
Do you have a history of drug use?
Well yes. I am detoxing.
What kind of drugs have you been using?
Heroin.
Okay. How long have you been using?
I don't feel well. Maybe a year. I can't sleep or eat.
Have you had a fever, chills, vomiting or diarrhea?
I think I have a fever. I feel chilled. I have had some diarrhea.

conversations.context: This is a 62-year-old female who previously underwent a repair of rotator cuff.  She continued to have pain within the shoulder.  She had a repeat MRI performed, which confirmed the clinical diagnosis of re-tear of the rotator cuff.  She wished to proceed with a repair.  All risks and benefits of the surgery were discussed with her at length.  She was in agreement with the above treatment plan.

dialogue.message: Good afternoon, ma'am.
Good afternoon, doctor.
Remind me, how young are you?
Oh doctor, you flatter me. I'm sixty two years old.
Great, and you've had a rotator cuff repair before, correct?
Yes, that's correct.
Good, well, what seems to be the problem today?
I'm still having a lot of pain in this shoulder.
Oh no, have you had any recent imaging done on this shoulder?
Yes, I had an M R I not too long ago, can you take a look? I have it right here.
Thank you, yes, um, this M R I shows that you've torn that rotator cuff again.
Oh no, can we do another surgery to repair it again?
Yes, we'll have to.
What's the risk of infection of the surgery?
Its less than one percent. We'll use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
Will I be asleep again?
Yes, you won't feel a thing.
Great, yes, I'd like to go forward with the surgery. I need to get back to playing tennis.

conversations.context: Spontaneous Vaginal delivery at 36weeks gestation to a G2P1 mother. Birth weight 7#10oz. No instrumentation required. Labor = 11hours. "Light gas anesthesia" given. Apgars unknown. Mother reportedly had the "flu" in the 7th or 8th month of gestation. Patient discharged 5 days post-partum. Development: spoke first words between 1 and 2 years of age. Rolled side to side at age 2, but did not walk. Fed self with hands at age 2 years. Never toilet trained.

dialogue.message: Welcome in. I am Doctor Welch.
Guest_family: Thank you! It is nice to meet you.
How old is your daughter?
Guest_family: She is three years old now.
Hi there!
Hi!
Mom I would like to start off with some questions regarding pregnancy, childbirth, and prior children.
Guest_family: Okay.
Do you have any other children?
Guest_family: No. She is my only child.
Have you ever had any miscarriages or abortions prior to having your daughter?
Guest_family: I had a very early miscarriage before getting pregnant again with her.
I am so sorry to hear that.
Guest_family: Thank you. I was difficult but when I got pregnant again with her, we were so overjoyed.
Did you have any difficulties or problems during your pregnancy with her.
Guest_family: I had the flu in my seventh or eighth month of pregnancy. Other than that I had no problems.
How far along were you when you gave birth?
Guest_family: I was thirty six weeks.
Did you have a vaginal birth or a C section?
Guest_family: I had a regular birth.
Were any tools used during the birth to help with the birthing process?
Guest_family: No.
How long were you in labor for?
Guest_family: I was in labor for eleven hours.
Were you given any anesthesia during the birth?
Guest_family: They gave me a little bit of laughing gas but not much.
What was her birth weight?
Guest_family: Seven pounds and ten ounces.
Do you recall her Apgars score?
Guest_family: No. I am not sure.
How long did you stay in the hospital after the birth?
Guest_family: Five days.
Let us move to questions regarding your daughter. Has she had any development problems?
Guest_family: She did not walk until well after two years old. She only rolled from side to side at two.
Okay. How old was she when she spoke her first words?
Guest_family: She was around one or two.
When did she start to feed herself, using her hands?
Guest_family: She was two.
Has she been toilet trained yet?
Guest_family: No. She is not interested but I have been trying.

conversations.context: The patient returns to the Pulmonary Medicine Clinic for followup evaluation of interstitial disease secondary to lupus pneumonitis.  She was last seen in the Pulmonary Medicine Clinic in January 2004.  Since that time, her respiratory status has been quite good.  She has had no major respiratory difficulties; however, starting yesterday she began with increasing back and joint pain and as a result a deep breath has caused some back discomfort.  She denies any problems with cough or sputum production.  No fevers or chills.  Recently, she has had a bit more problems with fatigue.  For the most part, she has had no pulmonary limitations to her activity.

dialogue.message: Guest_clinician: Hello, doctor. Let me give you a run down as to what we are dealing with today. This patient was last seen in January two thousand and four. She is coming for a follow up on interstitial disease secondary to lupus pneumonitis. I will let her tell you more about what happened yesterday.
Thanks, nurse. How are you feeling today, miss? Welcome back to the Pulmonary Medicine Clinic. What happened yesterday?
Well, I was doing fine since last time. My respiratory issues have been great and I have had no major difficulties breathing.
That's good to hear. What happened yesterday that caused you to want to come in so urgently?
Yesterday I noticed that I have some back and joint pain.  When I breathe deep my back hurts.
Are you experiencing any coughing?
No, coughing at this moment.
Have you been producing any mucus the times that you do cough?
No, I already said I didn't cough.
Okay. Any fevers or chills?
Nothing so far.
Do you have any other symptoms currently?
I do notice that I am more tired than usual.
During physical activity do you seem out of breath or more tired than usual? I want to see if your pulmonary system is inhibited.
No. I don't have issues with breathing when I do daily activities.

conversations.context: This is a 79-year-old female who has disabling bilateral knee degenerative arthritis.  She has been unresponsive to conservative measures.  All risks, complications, anticipated benefits, and postoperative course were discussed.  The patient has agreed to proceed with surgery as described below.

dialogue.message: Good morning, ma'am. Before we begin today, can you confirm your age for me?
Good morning, doctor. Sure, I'm seventy nine years old.
Great, thank you. What seems to be the problem today, ma'am?
Well, I have this arthritis, as you know.
Yes, how would you describe your arthritis?
Well, at this point I'd say it's debilitating.
I see, so the antiinflammatories and rest haven't helped at all?
No, I haven't had any improvement, doctor. It's still so bad.
I see, I believe you'd be a good candidate for a knee replacement.
Yes, I thought so. What are the risks of infection for the surgery?
Um, it's less than one percent, we use prophylactic antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
That's great, what about anesthesia, will I be asleep for this?
Yes, you won't feel a thing.
Great, yes, I'd like to do the surgery, doctor.

conversations.context: The patient is to come to the hospital for bilateral L5 kyphoplasty.  The patient is an 86-year-old female with an L5 compression fracture. The patient has a history of back and buttock pain for some time.  She was found to have an L5 compression fracture.  She was treated conservatively over several months, but did not improve.  Unfortunately, she has continued to have significant ongoing back pain and recent CT scan has shown a sclerosis with some healing of her L5 compression fracture, but without complete healing.  The patient has had continued pain and at this time, is felt to be a candidate for kyphoplasty. She denies bowel or bladder incontinence.  She does complain of back pain.  She has been wearing a back brace and corset.  She does not have weakness.

dialogue.message: How old are you?
I'm eighty six years old.
What gender do you identify with?
I identify as a female.
How long have you had this back and buttock pain?
Its been a while, now. I know I have a fracture in my lower back.
How have you been managing this?
Another doctor called this conservative treatment. I've been resting a lot, and using antiinflammatories.
Has there been any improvement?
Its been several months at this point, and honestly no, there's been no improvement. I'm still in a lot of pain.
This C T Scan you had recently shows sclerosis, with some healing of a L five compression fracture, but if you look here, the healing is not complete.
What can we do about this? I'm in so much pain.
I believe you'd be a candidate for a bilateral L five kyphoplasty.
What's that?
It's a small procedure on that L five vertebra. Its minimally invasive, and we can actually do it as an outpatient procedure.
Oh, wow, that's good to hear. What are the risks of infection?
Very low, historically, they're less than one percent.
How is this possible?
We'll use antibiotics in order to control for infection.
That's great, will I be under anesthesia?
Yes, you'll be asleep for the whole thing.
Great, yes, I'd like to have this done, I can't keep living in this pain.
Awesome, I agree. Do you have control over your bladder and bowel movements?
Yes, thankfully, I have complete control over everything like that still.
Do you wear a brace or corset normally?
Yes, I usually wear both.
Okay, last question, can you notice any weakness in your body?
No, I'm still very strong, even at my age.

conversations.context: The patient is an 11-month-old with neuroblastoma, which initially presented on the left when he was 6 weeks old and was completely resected.  It was felt to be stage 2.  It was not N-Myc amplified and had favorable Shimada histology.  In followup, he was found to have a second primary in his right adrenal gland, which was biopsied and also consistent with neuroblastoma with favorable Shimada histology.  He is now being treated with chemotherapy per protocol P9641 and not on study.  He last received chemotherapy on 05/21/07, with carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin.  He received G-CSF daily after his chemotherapy due to neutropenia that delayed his second cycle.  In the interval since he was last seen, his mother reports that he had a couple of days of nasal congestion, but it is now improving.  He is not acted ill or had any fevers.  He has had somewhat diminished appetite, but it seems to be improving now.  He is peeing and pooping normally and has not had any diarrhea.  He did not have any appreciated nausea or vomiting.  He has been restarted on fluconazole due to having redeveloped thrush recently.

dialogue.message: Hello, Nurse. Could you give me a run down on the eleven month old patient?

Guest_clinician: The patient was presented with stage two neuroblastoma on the left when he was six weeks old. It was completely resected. It was shown not to be N Myc amplified and had some favorable Shimada histology.
Great. Did he have a follow up after?
Guest_clinician: He did. There was a second primary in his right adrenal gland. They performed a biopsy, which was consistent with neuroblastoma with favorable Shimada histology.
Did he receive any chemotherapy?

Guest_clinician: He is now being treated with it per protocol P nine six four one and not on study. His last chemotherapy appointment was on May twenty first two thousand and seven. They used carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin.
What did they do after chemotherapy?
Guest_clinician: He received G C S F daily because he had neutropenia that delayed his second cycle.
Thank you, Nurse. I'll go talk to the mother.
Guest_clinican: No problem, Doctor.
Hello, ma'am. It's nice to see you again. How is your little boy doing?
Guest_family: Not so well. Since out last visit, he had a stuffy nose for a couple of days.
Is it getting worse?
Guest_family: I think it's getting better now. It isn't as stuffy.
That's good to hear. Has he been sick or had any fevers?
Guest_family: Nope. Just the stuffy nose.
Has he been able to eat anything?
Guest_family: At times, he didn't want to eat. It seemed like he wasn't hungry.
Does he still have a reduced appetite?
Guest_family: Not anymore. He's starting to eat again.
Did he have any nausea or vomiting after he ate?
Guest_family: Thankfully, no. I would have made my husband clean up the vomit.
That's great. Is he able to pee and poop fine? No diarrhea, right?
Guest_family: His poop has been solid. I haven't seen anything bad about his pee either.
Great. Would you be able to open his mouth for me? I just want to check if everything's fine inside.
Guest_family: Of course. Say ah.
Ah.
Thank you. Oh, wow. It looks like he's showing some symptoms of thrush again.
Guest_family: Oh, no. Should we restart fluconazole?
It's just a fungal infection inside the mouth. I'll prescribe him fluconazole. It should get rid of it.
Guest_family: Thank you so much. You all have been so helpful. My little boy is slowly getting better.

conversations.context: This is a 34-year-old male with history of back pain with radiation into the left leg in the S1 nerve root distribution.  The patient was lifting at work on 08/27/03 and felt immediate sharp pain from his back down to the left lower extremity.  He denied any previous history of back pain or back surgeries.  Because of his intractable pain as well as severe weakness in the S1 nerve root distribution, the patient was aware of all risks as well as possible complications of this type of surgery and he has agreed to pursue on.  After an informed consent was obtained, all risks as well as complications were discussed with the patient.

dialogue.message: Um, I take the generic for Ultracet. Sometimes I take as many as four times a day.
Does this help the pain?
No, I'm still in pretty significant pain, doctor.
Good morning, sir. My nurse's chart says that you're thirty four years old. Is that correct?
Yes, doctor, that's correct.
How long have you had this back pain?
Well, it's been a while now.
Does the pain go into your legs?
Yes, into the left leg, more towards the outside of my leg.
Is there any injury that started this pain?
Yeah, I was lifting at work on August twenty seventh two thousand three when I lifted something and felt a pretty sharp pain from my back down into my left leg.
Have you had back pain or surgeries before this injury?
No, I haven't.
Are you having weakness in the legs?
Yes, I am.
Okay, I believe you are a good candidate for surgery, sir. It seems like you have a lot of weakness and pain in the S one nerve root distribution.
Okay. What are the risks of infection for this surgery?
Overall, the risk of infection is very low, less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
Will I be asleep for the surgery?
Yes, you'll be under anesthesia. You won't feel a thing.
Okay, yes. I'd like to do the surgery.

conversations.context: The patient was instructed to contact us with any questions or concerns that may arise.  In addition, he was instructed to contact us, if he would have fevers greater than 101.4, chills, nausea or vomitting, continuing diarrhea, redness, drainage, or warmth around his incision site.  He will be seen in about one week's time in Dr. XYZ's clinic and his staples will be removed at that time.

dialogue.message: We have you scheduled for a follow up and to have the staples removed in one week with Doctor X Y Z. Do you have your wound care instructions?
Yes.
Do you have any questions?
No.
If you do have questions or concerns that may come up, please don't hesitate to call the office.
Okay.

If you develop a fever greater than one hundred and one point four, chills, nausea, vomiting, or continuing diarrhea please call the office. Also if your incision site becomes red, warm to the touch or has any drainage, call the office.
Okay.

conversations.context: I think this is still his allergic rhinitis rather than a sinus infection.

dialogue.message: Have you had sinus issues before?
I am not sure, maybe on and off.
Because this is more allergic.
Okay.
So, we call it allergic rhinitis.
Is it different than sinus infection?
Yes, it's it is different.
Okay.

conversations.context: Significant for asthma, allergic rhinitis and cervical dysplasia.

dialogue.message: So, to double check, you have a history of hay fever and asthma, correct?
Yes. I was also recently diagnosed with cervical dysplasia. I found out shortly after my last O B G Y N visit.
And are you planning to follow up with your O B G Y N in the upcoming months?
Yeah, the next visit is scheduled and everything.

conversations.context: Chest x-ray ordered by ER physician is unremarkable, but to me also.

dialogue.message: I have reviewed your x rays from your emergency room visit. I agree with Doctor Jones that your lungs show no signs of infection or decreased lung capacity.
Okay.

conversations.context: The patient is a very pleasant 57-year old white female, a native of Cuba, being seen for evaluation and treatment of sores in her mouth that she has had for the last 10-12 days.  The patient has a long history of severe and debilitating rheumatoid arthritis for which she has had numerous treatments, but over the past ten years she has been treated with methotrexate quite successfully.  Her dosage has varied somewhere between 20 and 25 mg per week.  About the beginning of this year, her dosage was decreased from 25 mg to 20 mg, but because of the flare of the rheumatoid arthritis, it was increased to 22.5 mg per week.  She has had no problems with methotrexate as far as she knows.  She also took an NSAID about a month ago that was recently continued because of the ulcerations in her mouth.  About two weeks ago, just about the time the stomatitis began she was placed on an antibiotic for suspected upper respiratory infection.  She does not remember the name of the antibiotic.  Although she claims she remembers taking this type of medication in the past without any problems.  She was on that medication three pills a day for three to four days.  She notes no other problems with her skin.  She remembers no allergic reactions to medication.  She has no previous history of fever blisters.

dialogue.message: Hi there! What brings you back to see me so soon?
Hi! I have had these sores in my mouth.
How long have you had the sores?
They started about ten to twelve days ago.
We have been currently treating your rheumatoid arthritis with methotrexate. How much have you been taking?
Yes, we have tried lots of different treatments and methotrexate has been working well.  I have been on it for ten years now. I have been taking about twenty or twenty five M G of per week.
Did we recently increase your dosage? I see in your chart that we have changed your dosage a few times.
About a year ago we lowered the dosage for twenty five M G to twenty but my arthritis flared up so we went to twenty two point five.
Have you ever had any side effects from the methotrexate in the past?
No. I don't think so.
Are you taking any other medications?
I had a sinus infection and the doctor put me on an antibiotic. That was about two weeks ago.
Do you know what the antibiotic the doctor gave you?
I don't remember the name of the antibiotic, but I know that I have taken antibiotics before and I didn't have a problem.
How long was your antibiotic course?
It was three or four days long. I had to take it three times a day.
Have you ever had any allergic reactions to medications?
No.
Any history of mouth sores?
No.
Are you taking anything to help with the pain of the mouth sores?
I took Aspirin a month ago. I started taking it again because my mouth was sore.
Have you had any other problems with your skin? Any new rashes?
No.
Sorry to side track, but where is your accent from? My family is Cuban and my mom and you speak the same.
What a surprise! I am Cuban. A proud fifty seven year old Cuban.

conversations.context: This is a 78-year-old male who is complaining of right hand pain and numbness with decreased range of the middle index finger and right middle finger complaining of catching and locking.  The patient was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome on bilateral hands the right being worse than the left.  He had positive EMG findings as well as clinical findings.  The patient did undergo an injection, which only provided him with temporary relief and is for this reason, he has consented to undergo the above-named procedure. All risks as well as complications were discussed with the patient and consent was obtained.

dialogue.message: Good afternoon, sir. Did you see the nurse already?
Yes, I just saw her.
Great, you're seventy eight years old, correct?
Yes, I'm not as young as I used to be.
Who is? What seems to be the problem today, sir?
I have right hand pain, and it's been there for a while now.
Are you having numbness sir?
Yes, and I can't move it very well, either.
Which fingers are you having these symptoms in?
Well, I told you it's all in the right hand, but it's in the index and middle fingers.
Are your fingers catching?
What does that mean, doctor?
Are you having any problems extending your fingers?
Yes, they seem to lock up when I try to extend my fingers.
Have you seen another doctor for this?
Yes, I had an E M G and it showed, um, carpal tunnel on both hands.
It's in both hands, but the right is worse than the left, correct?
Yes, that's correct.
What treatments have you had for this?
I only had an injection so far.
Did this help at all?
Well, some, but it was really only temporary relief. Is there surgery for this?
Yes, I think you'd be a good candidate for surgery.
What are the risks of infection from the surgery?
It's less than one percent. We use prophylactic antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
Even though it's on my hand, will I be asleep for this procedure?
Yes, you won't feel a thing.
Okay, yes. I'd like to do the surgery.

conversations.context: The patient is a 65-year-old female who underwent left upper lobectomy for stage IA non-small cell lung cancer.  She returns for a routine surveillance visit. She has undergone since her last visit an abdominopelvic CT, which shows an enlarging simple cyst of the left kidney.  She underwent barium swallow, which demonstrates a small sliding hiatal hernia with minimal reflux.  She has a minimal delayed emptying secondary tertiary contractions.  PA and lateral chest x-ray from the 11/23/09 was also reviewed, which demonstrates no lesions or infiltrates.  Review of systems, the patient continues to have periodic odynophagia and mid thoracic dysphagia.  This most likely is secondary to tertiary contractions with some delayed emptying.  She has also had increased size of the left calf without tenderness, which has not resolved over the past several months.  She has had a previous DVT in 1975 and 1985.  She denies weight loss, anorexia, fevers, chills, headaches, new aches or pains, cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath at rest, or dyspnea on exertion.

dialogue.message: Good morning, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me, please?
Good morning, I'm sixty five years old, doctor.
How are you recovering from your operation?
I'm doing okay. Can you remind me what operation I had?
Um, we did a left upper lobectomy for your stage I A non small cell lung cancer.
Thank you, doctor.
Absolutely, do you have the results of your pelvic C T?
Yes, I have the report right here.
Thank you, so this shows an enlarging simple cyst of the left kidney.
What can we do about this?
Well, that's why we did the barium swallow, which showed a small hiatal hernia with minimal reflux.
Oh, yeah, I remember that.
So, I have your x rays from November twenty third two thousand nine here, we did an A P and lateral view, and they're normal.
Oh, well that's good too.
Are you having any pain with swallowing food?
Yes, I get some chest pain, but I'd say it's pretty mild. Look at my calf, doctor, it's much bigger than the right one.
Chest pain is probably due to tertiary contractions with some delayed emptying. Is it tender?
No, there's no real tenderness.
How long has this calf been enlarged?
Um, it's been several months at this point.
Have you ever had D V T?
Yes, um, in nineteen seventy five, and in nineteen eighty five.
Are you having any abnormal weight loss?
No, everything is normal there, and I'm eating normally.
What about any cold or flu symptoms? Any fever or chills?
No, that's all fine too.
Any new aches or pains?
No, all my muscles feel pretty good.
Have you had a cough, or coughed up any blood.
That's a negative, doctor.
What about shortness of breath while at rest or difficulty breathing with exercise?
No, that's normal too. I'm breathing just fine.

conversations.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No fever. ENT:  Not remarkable. RESPIRATORY:  No cough or shortness of breath. CARDIOVASCULAR:  The patient denies chest pain. GASTROINTESTINAL:  No nausea.  No vomiting.  No history of GI bleed. GENITOURINARY:  No dysuria.  No hematuria. ENDOCRINE:  Negative for diabetes or thyroid problems. NEUROLOGIC:  No history of CVA or TIA. Rest of review of systems is not remarkable.

dialogue.message: Any fever?
No.
No nausea and vomiting or black stool? Did you notice any blood in your stools?
Nope, nothing like that.
Did you notice any blood in urine or painful urination?
No.
Okay, any chest pain?
Um, no.
Any shortness of breath, cough or cold like symptoms?
Nope.
No diabetes or thyroid problem, right?
Absolutely not!
Looks like you have no history of C V A or stroke.
Correct.
Everything else looks fine.
Cool.
Your eyes, nose, and throat look good.

conversations.context: The patient is a 76-year-old white female who presents to the clinic today originally for hypertension and a med check.  She has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, allergic rhinitis and kidney stones.  Since her last visit she has been followed by Dr. Kumar.  Those issues are stable.  She has had no fever or chills, cough, congestion, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, chest pressure.

dialogue.message: What brings you back to the clinic today, Miss? Patient: I came for a refill of my blood pressure medication.
