It seems that Dr. Kumar followed with you the last time about your hypertension, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, allergic rhinitis and kidney stones. Have you noticed any changes or have you any concerns about these problems? Patient: No.  Have you had fever or chills, cough, congestion, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, chest pressure? Patient: No.  Super. Also, for our records, what age and race do you identify as? Patient: I am seventy-six years old and I identify you as a white woman.

conversations.context: Prescribed medications were Salmeterol inhaler, prn; and Fluticasone nasal inhaler. The patient was taking no over the counter or alternative medicines.

dialogue.message: Do you take any counter medicine? Patient: No, only those that have been prescribed.  No alternative medicine, naturopathy or anything? Patient: No, only what is here in this prescription.  Okay let me take a look... so you have been prescribed Salmeterol Inhaler- Patient: Based on needs.  Okay and the other is Fluticasone Inhaler, which is- Patient: Which is a nasal inhaler.  Okay.

conversations.context: The patient is an 89-year-old lady.  She actually turns 90 later this month, seen today for a short-term followup.  Actually, the main reasons we are seeing her back so soon which are elevated blood pressure and her right arm symptoms are basically resolved.  Blood pressure is better even though she is not currently on the higher dose Mavik likely recommended.  She apparently did not feel well with the higher dose, so she just went back to her previous dose of 1 mg daily.  She thinks, she also has an element of office hypertension.  Also, since she is on Mavik plus verapamil, she could switch over to the combined drug Tarka.  However, when we gave her samples of that she thought they were too big for her to swallow.  Basically, she is just back on her previous blood pressure regimen.  However, her blood pressure seems to be better today.  Her daughter says that they do check it periodically and it is similar to today's reading.  Her right arm symptoms are basically resolved and she attributed that to her muscle problem back in the right shoulder blade.  We did do a C-spine and right shoulder x-ray and those just mainly showed some degenerative changes and possibly some rotator cuff injury with the humeral head quite high up in the glenoid in the right shoulder, but this does not seem to cause her any problems.  She has some vague 'stomach problems', although apparently it is improved when she stopped Aleve and she does not have any more aches or pains off Aleve.  She takes Tylenol p.r.n., which seems to be enough for her.  She does not think she has any acid reflux symptoms or heartburn.  She does take Tums t.i.d. and also Mylanta at night.  She has had dentures for many, many years and just recently I guess in the last few months, although she was somewhat vague on this, she has had some sores in her mouth.  They do heal up, but then she will get another one.  She also thinks since she has been on the Lexapro, she has somewhat of a tremor of her basically whole body at least upper body including the torso and arms and had all of the daughters who I not noticed to speak of and it is certainly difficult to tell her today that she has much tremor.  They do think the Lexapro has helped to some extent.

dialogue.message: I hear someone has a birthday coming up, how old are you turning, ma'am?
I'll be ninety later this month, doctor.
You're here for a follow up not very long after your first visit. What seems to be the problem today?
Well, actually, my high blood pressure and right arm symptoms are basically gone.
Great, I saw your blood pressure reading for today, and it's much better. Are you taking the higher dose of Mavik we recommended?
No, I'm not taking that right now.
How did you tolerate the higher dose?
I didn't feel well at all, so I just went back to the old dose.
That was one M G per day, correct?
Yes, doctor. I do think I could have some white coat high blood pressure. Doctors' offices make me nervous.
That does happen. Here, try this sample of Tarka, please.
What is this for, doctor?
Well, since you're taking the Mavik plus verapamil, you can switch over to Tarka, which is the combined version of the two drugs.
I can't take these, doctor. They're too big.
Guest_family: Hello doctor, I'm her daughter. Just so you know, we check her blood pressure at home periodically and it's always similar to that reading.
Good, so back to that right arm, how is that doing today?
Well, that pain is basically gone now, I think it had to do with that muscle problem back in my right shoulder blade.
Did you have x rays taken today?
Yes, the tech brought me back right before you came in.
Good, I have the images right here.
What do they show, doctor?
Well, these x rays of the neck and right shoulder show some degenerative changes, and possibly some kind of rotator cuff injury.
What makes you think there's an injury?
Well, look right here. The humeral head is pretty high in the glenoid in the right shoulder, but do you have any pain here?
No, none.
Then we won't worry about it.
I am having this stomach pain though, doctor.
How has this pain developed and progressed recently?
Well, it's improved somewhat with me not taking Aleve anymore.
What medicines are you taking right now, then?
Right know, I'm just taking Tylenol as needed. That seems to be enough for me.
Do you think this could be acid reflux, or heartburn?
No, but I take Tums, um, three times a day, and Mylanta at night. Oh yeah, I have these sores in my mouth, can you take a look?
I see. How long have you worn dentures?
Oh I couldn't even tell you, it's been many, many years.
Do they come and go, the sores?
Yes, one will come, then it'll heal up, then another.
Okay, we'll keep an eye on it.
And doctor, since I've been taking the Lexapro, I have some tremors on basically my whole body, at least the upper body, like my torso and arms.
It's hard to tell if you have a tremor today, ma'am, but do you think the Lexapro is helping otherwise?
Yes, we think so.

conversations.context: Intractable nausea and vomiting.

dialogue.message: When did nausea and vomiting begin? Patient: About a few hours ago. I can't seem to stomach anything.  How many episodes of vomiting have you had? Patient: At least four.  Any abdominal pain, fever, chill, or other symptoms? Patient: Just nausea and vomiting.

conversations.context: The patient presents today for followup.  No dysuria, gross hematuria, fever, chills.  She continues to have urinary incontinence, especially while changing from sitting to standing position, as well as urge incontinence.  She is voiding daytime every 1 hour in the morning especially after taking Lasix, which tapers off in the afternoon, nocturia time 0.  No incontinence.  No straining to urinate.  Good stream, emptying well.  No bowel issues, however, she also indicates that while using her vaginal cream, she has difficulty doing this as she feels protrusion in the vagina, and very concerned if she has a prolapse.

dialogue.message: I'm going to ask you a few regular questions, okay? Patient: Of course.  Any pain in urine? Patient: No.  Any fever or chills? Patient: None of them.  Did you notice any blood during urine? Patient: No. I'm fleeing, especially when I change my positions as if I sat down to stand up so I feel that there's a certain involuntary urination. It's more like a craving. I'm charging data as every one hour in the morning, especially when I take this Lasix.  Do you apply a lot of force to the urine? Patient: No.  How does this flow? Do you feel nothing.  Any leak in the night doesn't take place. Patient: No.

conversations.context: As in HPI. Patient and daughter also deny weight loss, fevers, chills, sweats, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain. She has had some difficulty expressing herself, but seems to comprehend speech as above. The patient has had a history of chronic urinary tract infections and her drainage is similar to past episodes when she has had such infection.

dialogue.message: Have you lost weight? Patient: No, I don't have, you can ask my daughter.  How about something like fever, nausea, vomiting, pain? Pattor: No.  And as we discussed you have problems talking and understanding. Pattor: Yes.  And you get urine infections too? Pattor: Yes.  And as discussed, your drainage is similar to past episodes when you had such an infection? Pattor: Yes.

conversations.context: LYMPH: No neck, axillary or groin adenopathy was noted.

dialogue.message: I'm going to do a quick exam on you. Patient: What kind of exam?  I'm just checking the lymph nodes. Every time there's an infection, these guys are the first to be noticed with the swelling.  Okay, so we'll first check your neck area. It looks good. I don't feel any inflamed lymph nodes. Your armpits also seem good and the last place to check is your groin area. It's all good. No sign of infection.

conversations.context: Significant for moderate to severe aortic stenosis, urinary tract infection, hypertension, chronic kidney disease (although her creatinine is near normal).

dialogue.message: Can you tell me what problems you've had in the past. Or what medical problems are going on? Patient: You mean my heart problem and things?  Yes. Patient: Okay, I've had hypertension and kidney problems for many years.  Okay. Patient: I get frequent urinary infections.  Your urine creatinine is normal. Patient: Okay. I also have severe aortic stenosis.

conversations.context: Significant for depression and reflux disease.

dialogue.message: So what are the stomach symptoms you feel? Patient: I feel an intense burn in my throat.  When do you feel that? Pattor: It really hurts after eating food, especially junk food.  It's quite consistent with reflux disease. Pattor: Ah, yes.  I have the results of your survey as well, let's discuss it. Pattor: Absolutely, please, what does it show.  According to your answers, it seems that you also have depression.

conversations.context: This is a 16-year-old white female who presents here to the emergency department in a private auto with her mother for evaluation of headache.  She indicates intense constant right frontal headache, persistent since onset early on Monday, now more than 48 hours ago.  Indicates pressure type of discomfort with throbbing component.  It is as high as a 9 on a 0 to 10 scale of intensity.  She denies having had similar discomfort in the past.  Denies any trauma. Review of systems:  No fever or chills.  No sinus congestion or nasal drainage.  No cough or cold symptoms.  No head trauma.  Mild nausea.  No vomiting or diarrhea.  Other systems reviewed and are negative.

dialogue.message: What is the race you identify as? Patient: White.  Are you okay? You have a headache? Patient: No, I have a very bad migraine.  Okay, can you indicate where you feel it most? Patient: Here, since Monday.  Agree for most of the right frontal side and it's been forty-eight hours now? Patient: Yes, I feel a lot of pressure.  I can understand the discomfort. Is it continuous or agitated? Patient: He is agitated.  On the scale of one to ten, ten being the worst, how would you judge it? Patient: Nine or more.  Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past? Patient: No I didn't.  Have you hit your head buy a chance? Patient: No.  Can you tell me if you have fever or chills, congestion, cold cough as symptoms? Patient: No.  Have you hit your head?

conversations.context: Mother is 50 and healthy.  Dad is 40 and healthy.  Half-sister, age 34, is healthy.  She has a sister who is age 10 who has some yeast infections.

dialogue.message: Can you tell me more about your parents, please? How are they? Patient: Thank you for asking, they're both doing well.  How old are they? Patient: My mother is fifty years old, and my father is forty years old.  Wonderful, do you have brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes, I have two sisters, one is a half-sister, and the other we have the same mother and dad.  How old are they? Patient: My half-sister and I have the same mother, and she is thirty-four years old. My other sister is ten years old.  Do they have a history of diseases that you know? Patient: My half-sister, um, no. My other sister has had yeast infections.

conversations.context: Clinical sinusitis and secondary cough.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: So, you mean it's something simple?  Yes, it's probably a sinus infection and then the cough secondary to this infection. Guest_family: Is it treatable?  Yes, it's. Guest_family: OK well.

conversations.context: 1.  Disseminated intravascular coagulation. 2.  Streptococcal pneumonia with sepsis.

dialogue.message: You have an infection that has become septic. We will have to start you with intravenous antibiotics. Patient: Okay.  We also have to treat blood clotting. I will give you an anticoagulant to avoid any other clotting problem. Do you have any questions? Patient: No.

conversations.context: This 76 y/o male complained of several months of generalized weakness and malaise, and a two week history of progressively worsening orthostatic dizziness. The dizziness worsened when moving into upright positions. In addition, he complained of intermittent throbbing holocranial headaches, which did not worsen with positional change, for the past several weeks. He had lost 40 pounds over the past year and denied any recent fever, SOB, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, hemoptysis, melena, hematochezia, bright red blood per rectum, polyuria, night sweats, visual changes, or syncopal episodes. He had a 100+ pack-year history of tobacco use and continued to smoke 1 to 2 packs per day. He has a history of sinusitis.

dialogue.message: Please represent the patient's case. Guest_clinician: The patient is a man of seventy-six years of age. He complains of generalized weakness and malaise for several months. He has a history of two weeks of worsening orthostatic dizziness. He denies recent symptoms of fever or shortness of breath, cough, vomiting, diarrhoea, haemoptysia, melena, haematochia, bright red blood per rectum, polyuria, night sweats, visual changes or syncopal episodes.  You said that you feel dizzy, which makes him worse? Patient: It's bad when I try to stay straight. I also have these intermittent headaches where he feels like someone inside.  Does these headaches change with changing positions or staying straight? Patient: No.  Does the patient have a known medical history? Guest_clinician: Yes, he has a history.

conversations.context: The patient seen and examined feels better today.  Still having diarrhea, decreased appetite.  Good urine output 600 mL since 7 o'clock in the morning.  Afebrile.

dialogue.message: How do you feel today, madam? Patient: Honestly, overall, I feel much better.  Do you still have diarrhea and decreased appetite? Patient: Yes, but I feel even better.  Have you pissed a normal amount? Patient: Yes, no problems there. I measured it as you said to me at six hundred M. L.  When did you piss for the last time? Patient: Hum, it was about seven this morning.  Do you have symptoms of fever? Patient: No, I feel good enough.

conversations.context: Upper respiratory infection.

dialogue.message: Your culture results have returned positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. This is a bacterial infection. I would like to take a course in antibiotics. This should start to improve your symptoms with in three to four days. Patient: OK.  Please let me know if your symptoms have not improved or get worse. Patient: I'm going. Thank you.

conversations.context: The patient is a 13-year-old female who had previous bilateral feet correction at 1 year of age.  Since that time, the patient has developed significant calcaneal valgus deformity with significant pain.  Radiographs confirmed collapse of the spinal arch, as well as valgus position of the foot.  Given the patient's symptoms, surgery is recommended for calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed with the mother.  Risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia; infection; bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  The patient will need to be strict nonweightbearing for at least 6 weeks and wear a brace for up to 6 months.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above surgical plan.

dialogue.message: Good morning, young lady. Is this your mother?
Yes, this is my mommy.
Good morning, mom. Can you tell me more about your daughter, please?
Guest_family: Good morning, doctor. Well, she's thirteen now, but she's had feet problems all her life.
What's been the problem with her feet?
Guest_family: Well, she had bilateral feet corrections when she was a year old.
Okay, how has she been since that procedure?
Guest_family: Well, just look at her heel, doctor.
Yes, I see. She has pretty significant calcaneal valgus deformity.
What does that mean, doctor?
Your heel is out of alignment, sweetie. Do you have pain?
Yes, I have a lot of pain, doctor.
Guest_family: What can we do about this, doctor?
Well, given all of her symptoms, I think we should do a calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening procedure.
Guest_family: What does that procedure entail?
Well, in short, we'll go in there and straighten everything out, and get everything lined back up.
Guest_family: What's the risk of infection with the surgery, sir?
Actually, it's less than one percent, so it's extremely low.
Guest_family: How is this possible, doctor?
We use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
Guest_family: That's great. Will she be asleep for this procedure?
Yes, we'll use anesthesia the entire time. She won't feel a thing.
Guest_family: Okay, that's good too. What about after the procedure? What's the protocol?
Well, I'll need your help. We have to be strict about her being nonweightbearing for six weeks at minimum.
Guest_family: Will she need a brace too?
Yes, at least for six months, but if she does everything I ask of her, it will be only six months.
Guest_family: Okay, yes, I think we should do the procedure. What do you think, honey?
Yes, I want to get back to playing sports with my friends.

The other risks include bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  I would not worry about these issues, though. It is quite rare. So, looking at her radiographs, the spinal arch is definitely collapsed. I think you guys are making the right decision.

conversations.context: Ten-system review significant for nausea, vomiting, fever, hemoptysis, and pleuritic chest pain.

dialogue.message: You have nausea, vomiting? Patient: Yes to both.  How about fever? Patient: Yes, I do.  No blood in sputum or chest pain? Patient: Yes, I do.

conversations.context: Otherwise negative for any recent febrile illnesses, chest pains or shortness of breath.

dialogue.message: How long do you have this cough? Patient: Three weeks past, Doc. Doc.: Do you raise something when you cough? Patient: No.  Any shortness of breath or chest pain? Patient: No.  How about fevers or chills? Patient: None of this.

conversations.context: 1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. 2. Mitral valve prolapse. 3. Stage IIIC papillary serous adenocarcinoma of the ovaries.

dialogue.message: Tell me about your medical history. Patient: I was diagnosed with stage three ovarian cancer two years ago. They found a tumor in my upper abdomen. I underwent surgery and they removed everything. Dr. King is my oncologist.  Are you still under treatment? Patient: Yes.  Do you have any other medical problems? Patient: Do you have a heart murmuring. It was not a problem. I also have acid reflux.  Do you take any medicine for G E R D? Patient: Yes. I am taking omeprazole.

conversations.context: I had the pleasure of meeting and evaluating the patient referred today for evaluation and treatment of chronic sinusitis.  As you are well aware, she is a pleasant 50-year-old female who states she started having severe sinusitis about two to three months ago with facial discomfort, nasal congestion, eye pain, and postnasal drip symptoms.  She states she really has sinus problems, but this infection has been rather severe and she notes she has not had much improvement with antibiotics.  She had a CT of her paranasal sinuses identifying mild mucosal thickening of right paranasal sinuses with occlusion of the ostiomeatal complex on the right and turbinate hypertrophy was also noted when I reviewed the films and there is some minimal nasal septum deviation to the left.  She currently is not taking any medication for her sinuses.  She also has noted that she is having some problems with her balance and possible hearing loss or at least ear popping and fullness.  Her audiogram today demonstrated mild high frequency sensorineural hearing loss, normal tympanometry, and normal speech discrimination.  She has tried topical nasal corticosteroid therapy without much improvement.  She tried Allegra without much improvement and she believes the Allegra may have caused problems with balance to worsen.  She notes her dizziness to be much worse if she does quick positional changes such as head turning or sudden movements, no ear fullness, pressure, humming, buzzing or roaring noted in her ears.  She denies any previous history of sinus surgery or nasal injury.  She believes she has some degree of allergy symptoms.

dialogue.message: I didn't have any nasal infections. Here's my report from my previous doctor who sent me back to you. Thank you. Let me look. I see here that you had severe sinusitis two to three months ago, is that correct? Patient: Is that what they call my nasal problems?  Yes, it is true. Sinusitis is the inflammation of your nasal airways. Patient: I see. Thank you for describing it to me. Patient: No problem. Could you describe to me what you felt two to three months ago? Patient: Yes, I can. My face would be uncomfortable, my nose was stifled, my eyes hurt, and I felt something you left in the back of my throat. Patient: Have you ever received any medicines?

conversations.context: Micronase 2.5 mg Tab PO QAM #30.  Bactrim 400/80 Tab PO BID #30.

dialogue.message: Do you still take Micronase every morning? Patient: Yes, I take um two points five M G once a day.  Great. Keep taking Micronase by mouth every day. As for your infection, I want you to start taking Bactrim twice a day. I will prescribe thirty pills. It will be Bactrim four hundred M G and eighty M G tablets.

conversations.context: Significant for recurrent UTIs as she was recently to the hospital about 3 weeks ago for urinary tract infection.  She has chronic incontinence and bladder atony, for which eventually it was decided for the care of the patient to put a Foley catheter and leave it in place.  She has had right-sided CVA.  She has had atrial fibrillation status post pacemaker.  She is a type 2 diabetic with significant neuropathy.  She has also had significant pain on the right side from her stroke.  She has a history of hypothyroidism.  Past surgical history is significant for cholecystectomy, colon cancer surgery in 1998.  She has had a pacemaker placement.

dialogue.message: I think three weeks ago for recurrent urinary infections.  Yes, it says here that you have bladder problems for a long time, mainly related to tone and ability. Patient: Yes, that's why they put me in catheter.  Okay and you have recently had the right side C V A? Patient: Yes, because of my heart problems, they had to put pacemaker in it.  Okay. Patient: I have hereditary diabetes.  Okay and your neuronal problem is also associated with that. Patient: That's true. Patient: You have pains on the right side now? Patient: Yes, because of my stroke.  And you are also taking thyroid medications? Patient: Yes, for my hypothyroidism.  Ok. Patient: Yes. Patient: What procedures have you had in the past? Patient: I have had many exact surgerys. They've taken my bladder, and now they've been put out of the biliary bladder.

conversations.context: A 14-day-old was seen by private doctor because of blister.  On Friday, she was noted to have a small blister near her umbilicus.  They went to their doctor on Saturday, culture was drawn.  It came back today, growing MRSA.  She has been doing well.  They put her on bacitracin ointment near the umbilicus.  That has about healed up.  However today, they noticed a small blister on her left temporal area.  They called the private doctor.  They direct called the Infectious Disease doctor here and was asked that they come into the hospital.  Mom states she has been diagnosed with MRSA on her buttocks as well and is on some medications.  The child has not had any fever.  She has not been lethargic or irritable.  She has been eating well up to 2 ounces every feed.  Eating well and sleeping well.  No other changes have been noted.

dialogue.message: Okay, tell me what's going on and what's brought you here.
Guest_family: I am her mother. She has this blister on the side of her head right above her ear, here. I was just worried and concerned about my baby.
How old is the baby? When did you first notice it?

Guest_family: She is just fourteen days old. Let me tell you from the beginning. On Friday, when I was taking her for a bath, I noticed a blister near her umbilicus area. We went to our doctor on Saturday, and they did a test.
Did you get the test result?
Guest_family: I got it today. Here is the report.
Okay, let me have a look. It says she is having a growing M R S A.
Guest_family: Yeah, I've been diagnosed with that too. And I am on medications. I had it on my buttock area.
Okay, so you know about it, and I don't have to explain it more.
Guest_family: Yeah.
So how is the blister on the umbilicus now?

Guest_family: She has been doing good. We put on some bacitracin ointment, and it almost healed up. But today I noticed that another small blister on her head. It really scared me, and I did not want to take any chance. That's why I reached out to the Infectious Disease center. I know it is private. But still, I don't want to take any chance with my baby's health. I called the center directly and they asked me to come to the hospital.
You did good. I will start the treatment. How are her eating and sleeping habits?
Guest_family: She hasn't missed any of her meals. She is taking around two ounces of milk in every feed. I don't think I have any issues with her eating or sleeping.
Did she have any fever?
Guest_family: Not that I noticed.
Has she been lethargic or crying more than normal?
Guest_family: No.
Any other changes in her daily routine that you might have noticed?
Guest_family: No, I didn't notice any changes.

conversations.context: The patient is a 7-year-old male who comes in today with a three-day history of emesis and a four-day history of diarrhea.  Apparently, his brother had similar symptoms.  They had eaten some chicken and then ate some more of it the next day, and I could not quite understand what the problem was because there is a little bit of language barrier, although dad was trying very hard to explain to me what had happened.  But any way, after he and his brother got done eating with chicken, they both felt bad and have continued to feel bad.  The patient has had diarrhea five to six times a day for the last four days and then he had emesis pretty frequently three days ago and then has just had a couple of it each day in the last two days.  He has not had any emesis today.  He has urinated this morning.  His parents are both concerned because he had a fever of 103 last night.  Also, he ate half of a hamburger yesterday and he tried drinking some milk and that is when he had an emesis.  He has been drinking Pedialyte, Gatorade, white grape juice, and 7Up, otherwise he has not been eating anything.

dialogue.message: Can you tell me more about your son, please? Guest_family: Well, he's seven years old, and he's had diarrhea for four days, and he's been vomiting for three days. Patient: Yes, my brother did this too. Guest_family: We had a little chicken one day, and then we had more of it the next day. After they ate they started to feel bad and still feel bad.  How many times did he have diarrhea a day from that beginning? Guest_family: Well, it was about five or six times a day during the last four days.  How many times did he vomit a day? Guest_family: Um, it was frequent.  Has he vomited today? Patient: No, I didn't have it today.  Did he go to the bathroom today? Patient: Yes, I pissed this morning.  He had symptoms of fever?

conversations.context: This is a 76-year-old female who has a history of previous pneumonia, also hypertension and macular degeneration, who presents with generalized body aches, cough, nausea, and right-sided abdominal pain for two days.  The patient stated that the abdominal pain was only associated with coughing.  The patient reported that the cough is dry in nature and the patient had subjective fevers and chills at home.

dialogue.message: Welcome to the clinic! I would like to start with your medical history. Patient: I have high blood pressure and macular deterioration. Last year I caught pneumonia but it became clear.  Okay. What brings you today? Patient: I had this cough and pain on the right side of my abdomen.  How long did it last? Patient: Two days. I had bodily pain and felt sick too.  Did you have a fever? Patient: I think so. I was cold and my forehead was hot. The cough is a dry cough.  Did abdominal pain occur during one of these cough episodes? Patient: Yes.

conversations.context: The patient complains of backache, stomachache, and dysuria for the last two days.  Fever just started today and cough.  She has history of kidney stones less than a year ago and had a urinary tract infection at that time.  Her back started hurting last night.

dialogue.message: What brings you today? Patient: My back started to hurt last night. I have stomach pain. I have had pain with urination for two days.  Do you have any other symptoms? Patient: I just coughed and now I have fever.  Do you have a history of kidney stones? Patient: Yes. I had kidney stones less than a year ago. I had a urinary infection at the same time. It was horrible.

conversations.context: 58 y/o female presents with a one year history of progressive loss of color vision. In the past two months she has developed blurred vision and a central scotoma OD. There are no symptoms of photopsias, diplopia, headache, or eye pain. There are no other complaints. There have been mild fluctuations of her symptoms, but her vision has never returned to its baseline prior to symptom onset one year ago.

dialogue.message: You are here today because you have difficulties of vision? Tell me what is happening, madame. Patient: Yes. It all started a year ago. It started with losing color in my vision.  Was the loss sudden or progressive? Patient: Gradual. And now I'm starting to have a blurred vision.  When did this start? Patient: I noticed it two months ago.  Is the blurred vision all blurred or is there a blind angle of blurred vision. Patient: It's a blurred vision and then I have a blind angle in my right eye.  Have you had any fluctuations of your symptoms over the last year? Do you have a vision back? Patient: Some days, I feel like a little better, but not much.

conversations.context: This is a return visit to the endocrine clinic for the patient with history as noted above.  She is 45 years old.  Her last visit was about 6 months ago.  Since that time, the patient states her health has remained unchanged.  Currently, primary complaint is one of fatigue that she feels throughout the day.  She states, however, she is doing well with CPAP and wakes up feeling refreshed but tends to tire out later in the day.  In terms of her thyroid issues, the patient states that she is not having signs or symptoms of thyroid excess or hypothyroidism.  She is not reporting temperature intolerance, palpitations, muscle weakness, tremors, nausea, vomiting, constipation, hyperdefecation or diarrhea.  Her weight has been stable.  She is not reporting proximal muscle weakness.

dialogue.message: I stayed relatively the same. My main complaint is that I feel tired throughout the day. The C P A P is doing well and I wake up refreshed, but I don't like how I crash.  Okay. How are the thyroid problems? Patient: I seem to be fine. My thyroid gland doesn't seem enlarged and I can breathe as normal. No fever or anything.  Have you experienced any of the following situations: temperature intolerance, palpitations, muscle weakness, tremors, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhoea? Patient: Nothing like it.  How was the weight? Patient: He was stable.  Any muscle weakness closest to the center of the body? Patient: No, nothing at all. Not bad for forty-five.

conversations.context: The patient is a 21-day-old Caucasian male here for 2 days of congestion - mom has been suctioning yellow discharge from the patient's nares, plus she has noticed some mild problems with his breathing while feeding (but negative for any perioral cyanosis or retractions).  One day ago, mom also noticed a tactile temperature and gave the patient Tylenol. Baby also has had some decreased p.o. intake.  His normal breast-feeding is down from 20 minutes q.2h. to 5 to 10 minutes secondary to his respiratory congestion.  He sleeps well, but has been more tired and has been fussy over the past 2 days.  The parents noticed no improvement with albuterol treatments given in the ER.  His urine output has also decreased; normally he has 8 to 10 wet and 5 dirty diapers per 24 hours, now he has down to 4 wet diapers per 24 hours.  Mom denies any diarrhea.  His bowel movements are yellow colored and soft in nature. The parents also noticed no rashes, just his normal neonatal acne.  The parents also deny any vomiting, apnea.

dialogue.message: How's the little guy? Guest_family: He has fever and bad congestion during the last two days. He's had fever for one. I'm trying to suck the discharge through the nose.  I guess he has some breathing problems during the diet. Guest_family: Yes, that's right. He drinks milk every two hours, only ten minutes instead of twenty minutes. Guest_family: He has fever too, so she gave him Tylenol. Guest_family2: He's very restless.  Is he sleeping well? Guest_family: Yes, he's sleeping. But he's not able to breathe well even with albuterol.  What's wrong with diarrhea and dirty diapers? Guest_family: He pisses less because he had between eight and ten wet diapers, but now it's up to four hours a day.

conversations.context: A 55-year-old female presents self-referred for the possibility of evaluation and treatment of allergies, diminished taste, xerostomia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, possible food allergies, chronic GI irritability, asthma, and environmental inhalant allergies.  Please refer to chart for history and physical and review of systems and detailed medical history.

dialogue.message: I think this is our first meeting. Patient: Hello, doctor. Yes, this is my first time.  Great, how old are you? Patient: I am fifty-five years old, doctor.  Thank you, what seems to be the problem today? Patient: Well, I have a list of the symptoms of laundry coinciding with my allergies.  Like what, ma'am? Patient: Well, my sense of taste is diminished, dry mouth, um, acid reflux, and G I problems, and then I have asthma, and reactions to things like aerosols.  I see, do you have food allergies? Patient: Hum, I think.

conversations.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  Denies weight loss/gain, fever or chills. ENMT:  Denies headaches, nosebleeds, voice changes, blurry vision or changes in/loss of vision. CV:  See history of present illness.  Denies chest pain, SOB supine, palpitations, edema, varicose veins or leg pains. RESPIRATORY:  He has a chronic cough.  Denies shortness of breath, wheezing, sputum production or bloody sputum. GI:  Denies heartburn, blood in stools, loss of appetite, abdominal pain or constipation. GU:  Denies painful/burning urination, cloudy/dark urine, flank pain or groin pain. MS:  Denies joint pain/stiffness, backaches, tendon/ligaments/muscle pains/strains, bone aches/pains or muscle weakness. NEURO:  Denies blackouts, seizures, loss of memory, hallucinations, weakness, numbness, tremors or paralysis. PSYCH:  Denies anxiety, irritability, apathy, depression, sleep disturbances, appetite disturbances or suicidal thoughts. INTEGUMENTARY:  Denies unusual hair loss/breakage, skin lesions/discoloration or unusual nail breakage/discoloration.

dialogue.message: No sudden gain or loss of weight? Patient: No.  No headache, bleeding of the nose, coarse voice, blurred vision or loss of vision. Patient: No, not at all.  No fever or chills, not at all. Patient: No fever or anything. Patient: No pain in the chest, shortness of breath or shortness of breath during sleep? Patient: No palpitation, swelling or varicose veins or pain in the legs? Patient: No pain in the throat or cough or cough with mucous membrane or sputum? Patient: I have this cough prolonged, but not anything. Patient: No breathing? Patient: No wheezing. Patient: No heart burn, nausea or vomiting? Patient: No pain in the stool or urine? Patient: No pain in the back or abdominal pain? Patient: No pain in the back or back. Patient: No pain in the back. Patient: No pain in the back.

conversations.context: Upper respiratory illness with apnea, possible pertussis.

dialogue.message: How does he feel today? Guest_family: I think it's the worst he's felt all week long.  I'm sorry to learn that he's not feeling well. What are the symptoms he's had? Guest_family: He's been very crowded for a long time and seems to cough much more than usual. He also suffered a fever yesterday.  I see. What was his temperature? Guest_family: The thermometer read one hundred and one degrees Fahrenheit. Should he go to hospital?  Let me evaluate and see what we can do for him today. Guest_family: Thank you, Doctor.  I suspect he has a superior respiratory infection, a possible whooping cough.

conversations.context: EXTERNAL GENITALIA: Normal for age.  Normal penis with bilaterally descended testes that are normal in size, shape, and contour, and without evidence of hernia or hydrocele.

dialogue.message: Okay, let me examine it quickly. Mom gives you permission? I will quickly check his genitals. Can you pull his pants down? Guest_family: Of course, you can check it out.  Well, everything looks good, his penis and testicles are the normal shape and size for his age. No accumulation of fluid or swelling in the scrotum area, no evidence of hernia there.

conversations.context: The patient denies any complaints, states that the right hand and left foot was very swollen and very painful, and came to emergency room.  Also, she could not urinate and states as soon as they put Foley in, 500 mL of urine came out.  Also they started her on steroids and colchicine, and the pain is improving and the swelling is getting better.  Denies any fever and chills.  Denies any dysuria, frequency or hematuria.  States that the urine output was decreased considerably, and she could not urinate.  Denies any cough, hemoptysis or sputum production.  Denies any chest pain, orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

dialogue.message: All right, but tell me what's going on and we can understand that. Patient: Okay, so my right hand and my left foot were very swollen and very painful, and that's why I came to the emergency room.  Do you have a bag of urine? Patient: Yes, I couldn't go for them to put it in.  Yes, it seems that five hundred ML have come out. So much possible urinary obstruction. Also, they started you on steroids and colchicin. How do you feel now? Patient: I feel a little better, my pain is getting better, and the swelling is getting better.  Okay, that's good. Any fever and chills? Pattor: No, no fever.  Any urine problem like pain or frequency or blood in the urine? Patient: No, but I'm not able to empty my bladder well, the pipi has decreased a lot, I couldn't urinate.  All right, I'll evaluate that.

conversations.context: Significant for pain in the buttock.  Otherwise negative.

dialogue.message: Okay. Patient: I have nothing else.  Okay, no fever, no nausea, nothing like that? Patient: No.

conversations.context: The patient is a two-and-a-half-month-old male who has been sick for the past three to four days.  His mother has described congested sounds with cough and decreased appetite.  He has had no fever.  He has had no rhinorrhea.  Nobody else at home is currently ill.  He has no cigarette smoke exposure.  She brought him to the emergency room this morning after a bad coughing spell.  He did not have any apnea during this episode.

dialogue.message: Hello! How do you do today? Guest_family: I am fine, but my son is sick. He is two and a half years old.  What are his symptoms? Guest_family: He has a bad cough. He has been sick for three or four days. There seems to be a phlegm that swings there when he coughs. He had a bad cough this morning. I was nervous and I decided to bring him.  During his cough episode this morning, did you notice a loss of breath or gas for air? Guest_family: No.  Did he have a rough nose? Guest_family: No.  No fever? Guest_family: No. He didn't eat much.  Was anyone else in the house sick? Guest_family: No.

conversations.context: A 66-year-old female with knee osteoarthrosis.  Failed conservative management.  Risks and benefits of different treatment options were explained.  Informed consent was obtained.

dialogue.message: Hello, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me? Patient: Well, doctor, I am now sixty-six years old.  Thank you, how is your knee going today? Let's hope that the osteoarthritis improves. Patient: It's so bad, doctor.  Have you had any improvements with the rest and anti-inflammatorys we talked about before? Patient: No, they didn't help at all.  I see, you would be a good candidate for knee replacement. Patient: What is the risk of surgery infection?  Historically, it's less than one percent, we use prophylaxis antibiotics to control infection all the time. Patient: Great, and will I sleep for that?  Yes, you won't feel anything.

conversations.context: GERD, hypertension times 20 years, arthritis, Parkinson's, TIA, chronic atrial fibrillation, on Coumadin three years.

dialogue.message: So I see you were diagnosed with acid reflux and high blood pressure 20 years ago? Patient: Yes.  And then you also have arthritis and Parkinson's. Patient: Yes, both.  Also, you had a cerebral stroke? Patient: Yes, mini-AVC!  Ah, yes. We also call him T I A. Patient: OK.  And now you're taking medication? Patient: Just Coumadin, for my chronicle A Fib. I've been there for three years.  Yes, atrial fibrillation. Patient: Yes.

conversations.context: The patient is 13-year-old male with persistent left knee pain.  He was initially seen at Sierra Pacific Orthopedic Group where an MRI demonstrated unstable OCD lesion of the left knee.  The patient presented here for a second opinion.  Surgery was recommended grossly due to the instability of the fragment.  Risks and benefits of surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery include risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion extremity, failure to relieve pain or restore the articular cartilage, possible need for other surgical procedures, and possible early arthritis.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Hello, young man. Patient: Hello, doctor.  How old are you, sir? Patient: I'm thirteen years old.  What brings you today? Guest_family: Well, at the beginning we went to Sierra Pacific Orthopaedic Group, and he had an MR that I showed, um, O C D in the left knee.  Yes, I see that in the report. Guest_family: So we're here for a second opinion on this.  Yes, we should do surgery on this knee. There's a serious instability of the fragment, and we don't want that to get worse. Guest_family: Ok, that's about what we've heard so far. What are the risks of infection of the procedure?  It's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control the infection.

conversations.context: Significant for her being without a companion at this point.  She was born in Munich, Germany.  She immigrated to of America in 1957 after her family had to move to Eastern Germany, which was under Russian occupation at that time.  She is divorced.  She used to work as a secretary and later worked as a clerical worker at IBM.  She stopped working more than 20 years ago due to complications from her mesothelioma.  She denies any significant tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs.  She is bilingual speaking, German and English.  She has known English from before her teens.  She has the equivalent of a high school education in Germany.  She has one brother and one sister, both of whom are healthy and she does not spend much time communicating with them.  She has one son who lives in Santa Cruz.  He has grandchildren.  She is trying to contact with her grandchildren.

dialogue.message: Patient: Yes, I always knew how to speak English before I was even a teenager. So, when I moved to America, I didn't have a language problem.  Okay and did you move with your family? Patient: No, my family moved to the eastern side of Germany that was occupied by Russia at that time, but I decided to move to America in nineteen fifty-seven years. Patient: I had a high school diploma from Germany, and I could speak German and English fluently. Patient: As soon as I landed here in America, I started working. I started as a secretary in a private company and later I worked at I B M. Now I am retired for almost twenty years because of my complications of cancer.  Your Mesothelioma? Patient: Yes.  Okay, and who are all there in your family? Patient: I am alone without a companion. I am a son who lives in Santa Cruz, he doesn't drink a lot.

conversations.context: Fever of unknown origin.

dialogue.message: When did you take your temperature for the last time? Patient: Just before I drive here.  I see. Did the nurse take your temperature when you entered? Patient: Yes, she did.  Did you experience a cold like symptoms such as cough, nasal congestion, headache or nausea? Patient: No, not really.  Did you try to take a medication to help with fever? Patient: Yes. I took Tylenol and it helped a little.  Have you had any recent sick contacts? Patient: I don't think so. I live with three other roommates and they seem good.

conversations.context: The patient is a 10-year-old boy who has been a toe walker since he started ambulating at about a year.  The patient had some mild hamstring tightness with his popliteal angle of approximately 20 degrees bilaterally.  He does not walk with a crouched gait but does toe walk.  Given his tightness, surgery versus observation was recommended to the family.  Family however wanted to correct his toe walking.  Surgery was then discussed.  Risks of surgery include risks of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremities, failure to resolve toe walking, possible stiffness, cast, and cast problems.  All questions were answered and parents agreed to above surgical plan.

dialogue.message: Can you tell me more about your son, please?
Guest_family: Sure, he's ten years old now.
How long has he used his walker?
Guest_family: Well, he's been using that since he started walking.
How old was he when he started walking?
Guest_family: He was about a year old.
Good, what seems to be the problem today?
Guest_family: He keeps complaining about the back of his legs being tight.
Can you sit on the table, young man? Yes, I'm bending his legs, we call this the popliteal angle, and both sides flex to only about twenty.
Guest_family: Where should that be normally?
He should be able to get to ninety.
Guest_family: What can we do about this?
I think we should do surgery on this leg. How does he walk? Can I see?
Guest_family: Well, just look at him.
Yes, he does not walk with a crouched pattern, but he is toe walking.
Guest_family: Can we correct that instead of the hamstring tightness?
Well, I believe he should have surgery on the hamstring, as well.
Guest_family: Okay, right now we want to do surgery to fix his walking. What are the risks of infection?

They're low, historically, they're less than one percent. The risks include anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and the motion of walking, and it may also not always cure the toe walking. There is also possible stiffness after wearing the cast and other cast issues.
Guest_family: Okay, and will be under anesthesia during this? Is this worth it?
Absolutely, he won't feel a thing. It is worth it because the chances of the risks happening are low.
Guest_family: Yes, we'd like to do the procedure. Let me text my husband really quick. Okay, yes, my husband agrees.

conversations.context: This is a 49-year-old white male who sustained a traumatic injury to his left posterior thighthis past year while in ABCD.  He sustained an injury from the patellar from a boat while in the water.  He was air lifted actually up to XYZ Hospital and underwent extensive surgery.  He still has an external fixation on it for the healing fractures in the leg and has undergone grafting and full thickness skin grafting closure to a large defect in his left posterior thigh, which is nearly healed right in the gluteal fold on that left area.  In several areas right along the graft site and low in the leg, the patient has several areas of hypergranulation tissue.  He has some drainage from these areas.  There are no signs and symptoms of infection.  He is referred to us to help him get those areas under control.

dialogue.message: I am forty-nine years old, and I identify myself as white.  Thank you. What brought you today? Patient: I was referred to you so that I could have everything that goes wrong with me under control.  I see. What is going on? Patient: I have a pain in my back of my leg this year when I was in A B C D.  What part of your leg? Patient: The back of my left thigh.  I see. Just the leg? Patient: I also have a pain in my knee of a boat when I was out fishing with water.  Was it serious? Patient: It was a complete spectacle. A helicopter came down and threw me to X Y Z infections?

conversations.context: The patient is a 76-year-old female who was referred to us from Dr. X for left flank pain.  The patient was found to have a left ureteral stone measuring about 1.3 cm in size per the patient's history.  The patient has had pain in the abdomen and across the back for the last four to five days.  The patient has some nausea and vomiting.  The patient wants something done for the stone.  The patient denies any hematuria, dysuria, burning or pain.  The patient denies any fevers.

dialogue.message: Doctor X has sent you back to us, is that correct? Patient: Yes. He is my primary care doctor.  It seems that you have a birthday to come. Happy birthday! Patient: Thank you. Yes, I'm going to be seventy-seven years old.  Dr. Kim's notes say you had pain in your left flank. Can you tell me more about the pain? Patient: Yes. The pain started four or five days ago. He was in my stomach and back on my left side. Here.  Okay. Did you have nausea or vomiting? Patient: Yes. I had nausea, and I vomited a few times.  Did you notice any blood, pain and/or burns during urination? Patient: No.  Any fever or chills? Patient: No.  I have the ultrasound results that Dr. X ordered the other day.

conversations.context: The patient is in complaining of headaches and dizzy spells, as well as a new little rash on the medial right calf.  She describes her dizziness as both vertigo and lightheadedness.  She does not have a headache at present but has some intermittent headaches, neck pains, and generalized myalgias.  She has noticed a few more bruises on her legs.  No fever or chills with slight cough.  She has had more chest pains but not at present.  She does have a little bit of nausea but no vomiting or diarrhea.  She complains of some left shoulder tenderness and discomfort.  She reports her blood sugar today after lunch was 155.

dialogue.message: I also noticed a new rash on my right calf.  Can you describe what kind of dizziness you have? What are they feeling? Patient: It's general dizziness and dizziness. I'm also dizzy during episodes.  Are you feeling well now or are you feeling symptoms? Patient: I have headaches and randomity, but nothing now. Neck pain and muscle pain are also intermittent.  Let me look at the rash on your legs. Are the bruises new? Patient: They are new, I think. I noticed them more than usual.  In the last few days you had fever or chills? Patient: No, nothing like that.  What is chest pain? Patient: I had a little tightness in my chest, but not now.

conversations.context: Chest x-ray revealed a diffuse pulmonary edema.

dialogue.message: Your chest x ray showed diffuse pulmonary edema. This means that you have fluid in your lungs. This would explain your chest pain and difficulties with your breathing. I would like to start with a course of antibiotics to prevent any possible infection. I will also send a prescription for Furosemide. This will reduce the accumulation of fluid in your lungs. Do you have any questions? Patient: When should I begin to feel better?  You should start to feel better within three to five days.

conversations.context: Mom's nipples are currently cracked and bleeding.  Mom has also noticed some mild umbilical discharge as well as some mild discharge from the penile area.  He is status post a circumcision.  Otherwise, review of systems is negative.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: My nipples are cracked, and they bleed.  Oh, I'm really sorry to hear that. Guest_family: He has a little fluid coming out of his belly button as well as his penis.  Okay, I'm going to look at it. But other than that, everything else looks good? Any other problem related to circumcision? Guest_family: No, no other problems.

conversations.context: This is a 56-year-old female who has pain in her legs at nighttime and when she gets up it comes and goes, radiates from her buttocks to her legs, sometimes it is her ankle.  She has noticed it since she has been on Lipitor.  She has had some night sweats occasionally.  She has had a little bit of fever and nausea.  She has noticed her blood sugars have been low.  She has lost over 30 pounds after exercising doing water aerobics at Genesis in Wichita.  She has noticed her fasting blood sugars have been ranging from 100 to 120.  Blood sugars one and a half hours after meals have been 185.  She is coming in for a diabetic checkup in one month and wants lab prior to that time.  She has been eating more meat recently and has not been on a diet for cholesterol.

dialogue.message: I'm here for this pain in my legs. It hurts especially in the night.  Does changing your position help you? Patient: Yes, it helps. Every time I'm standing, it just leaves.  Is it only in your legs where it starts there and goes elsewhere too? Patient: Normally starts in my hips and then it goes down my leg and sometimes in my ankles too.  When did you notice a first? Patient: Everything started after taking this medication. What does he call? Something with L? Yes, Lipitor.  Have you ever noticed night sweats? Patient: Sometimes I sweat at night.  Any other problem? Your body temperature is a little on the upper end. Patients: Yes, I feel feverish and nausea too.  How are your sugars? Patient: They have been low for a while.

conversations.context: Father died from CA at the age of 79.  Mother died from postoperative infection at the age of 81.  Brother died from pancreatitis at the age of 40 and had a prior history of mental illness.  Father also had a prior history of lung cancer.  Mother had a history of breast cancer.  Father also had glaucoma.  He does not have any living siblings.  Friend died a year and half ago.

dialogue.message: I'm Dr. Smith. Patient: Hello! It's nice to meet you.  Let's start with your family medical history. Patient: My mother had breast cancer. My father had lung cancer that ended up taking his life. He was seventy years old when he died. My mother also died but not of an illness but of an infection that she had after having had elective surgery.  I'm so sorry for your loss. How old was your mother when she died? Patient: Thank you. She was eighty years old when she died. I'm an orphan now. My only alive brother died at the age of forty. He had a difficult life. He had a mental illness.  How did your brother die? Patient: He had pancreatitis. Oh, my father had glaucoma.  You had a lot of loss. Patient: Yes, I have. My good friend died a year and a half ago.

conversations.context: A 47-year-old Latin American man presented to the emergency room after being told to come in for a high potassium value drawn the previous day. He had gone to an outside clinic the day prior to presentation complaining of weakness and fatigue. Labs drawn there revealed a potassium of 7.0 and he was told to come here for further evaluation. At time of his assessment in the emergency room, he noted general malaise and fatigue for eight months. Over this same time period he had subjective fevers and chills, night sweats, and a twenty-pound weight loss. He described anorexia with occasional nausea and vomiting of non-bilious material along with a feeling of light-headedness that occurred shortly after standing from a sitting or lying position. He denied a productive cough but did note chronic left sided upper back pain located in the ribs that was worse with cough and better with massage. He denied orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea but did become dyspneic after walking 2-3 blocks where before he had been able to jog 2-3 miles. He also noted that over the past year his left testicle had been getting progressively more swollen and painful. He had been seen for this at the onset of symptoms and given a course of antibiotics without improvement. Over the last several months there had been chronic drainage of yellowish material from this testicle. He denied trauma to this area. He denied diarrhea or constipation, changes in his urinary habits, rashes or skin changes, arthritis, arthralgias, abdominal pain, headache or visual changes.

dialogue.message: I will ask some simple questions, okay?
Hm
How old are you and how would you define yourself in terms of ethnicity?
Well, I am forty seven and would proudly call myself as Latin American.
Great. What brings you to the emergency room?
I had a blood test before and then it came out to be high potassium. I also went to a regular clinic the other day as I was feeling very weak and extremely tired.
Okay.

My potassium came out to be seven and it was highlighted in red. That really scared me, so I wanted to know everything what's going on inside me. I told the emergency doctors too that all these weakness and tiredness is going on for more than half a year.
Did you noticed any other symptoms other than weakness?

Yes, there was the fever and chills. I was sweating a lot in the nights, and I also had weight loss of around twenty pounds. During that time, I sometimes have nausea and was throwing up a lot. I was not eating. I always felt dizzy every time I tried to stand.
Did you have wet cough?
No, not wet cough but I did notice back pain gets intense on the upper side whenever I coughed, like in my ribs. I normally massage that area and it gets better.
Any shortness of breath?
Nope.
How about while sleeping or doing something else?

Not while sleeping, but I did notice that if I'm walking for two to three blocks then I get out of breath easily. Previously it was not like this. I used to jog for two to three miles without even a single breath loss.
I noticed one more thing. I feel like my balls on one side are getting big.
Which side left or right?
I think its left.
For how long?
I guess over the past year. I did see someone when all of this started, and he put me on some antibiotics, but nothing changed. For last few months there is yellow fluid coming out of it too.
Did you ever get any type of injury in the area?
No.
What about your bowel movements?
Nope everything is as usual.
Any change in urinary habits?
Nope.
Any changes in your skin? Any rash? Any kind of eyesight issue?
Nope, no changes.
What about pain? Like headache or any joint pain?
Nope, no pain anywhere.

conversations.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No history of fever, rigors, or chills except for recent fever and rigors. HEENT:  No history of cataract or glaucoma. RESPIRATORY:  Shortness of breath.  No pneumonia or valley fever. GASTROINTESTINAL:  Nausea and vomiting.  No hematemesis or melena. UROLOGICAL:  Frequency, urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No muscle weakness. SKIN:  None significant. NEUROLOGICAL:  No TIA or CVA.  No seizure disorder. PSYCHOLOGICAL:  No anxiety or depression.  HEMATOLOGICAL:  None significant.

dialogue.message: I also have chills.  Did you take anything for fever? Patient: Tylenol and Advil. I take them interchangeably.  When did you take your temperature for the last time? Patient: An hour ago. The thermometer read an O one point four.  Do you feel any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or others? Patient: I had a stronger desire to pee much more than usual. Patient: I don't know if it's related. Patient: It could be. We still wait on your urine results. Do you have a history of cataracts or glaucoma? Patient: No.  Very good. Any signs of pneumonia or valley fever? Patient: Nothing like that.

conversations.context: The patient is here for a follow-up.  The patient has a history of lupus, currently on Plaquenil 200-mg b.i.d.  Eye report was noted and appreciated.  The patient states that she is having some aches and pains of the hands and elbows that started recently a few weeks ago.  She denied having any trauma.  She states that the pain is bothering her.  She denies having any fevers, chills, or any joint effusion or swelling at this point.  She noted also that there is some increase in her hair loss in the recent times.

dialogue.message: Your prescription is two hundred MG twice a day, that's it.  Do you have a report on your eyes with you today? Patient: Yes, doctor. That's it.  Well, thank you, what's the problem today? Patient: Well, I have some pain in my hands and elbows.  When did you start this pain? Patient: It's been a few weeks now.  Is there a related trauma? Did you fall? Patient: No, no falls or anything. It just started one day, and it really bothers me.  Do you have fever or chills, or symptoms of cold or flu like that? Patient: No, I'm not.  How do you get a swelling? Are your joints swollen? Patient: No, everything is normal there.

conversations.context: All siblings are on antibiotics for ear infections and URIs.

dialogue.message: How are your other children? Guest_family: Not so wonderful. They're all on antibiotics.  For the same thing? Guest_family: Yes. They all have ear infections and chest colds.  Your hands are full then. Guest_family: Talk to me, doctor. I can't take a lot of breaks.  It's certainly a difficult winter for you and your family.

conversations.context: 1.  Disseminated CMV infection with possible CMV pneumonitis. 2.  Polymyositis on immunosuppressive therapy (methotrexate and prednisone).

dialogue.message: Guest_clinician: Is the patient admitted for a disseminated C M V infection?  Yes. I suspect that there is also a possible C M V pneumonitis. Guest_clinician: Are they immunosuppressive?  Yes. They have polymyositis and they take Prednisone and Methotrexate. Guest_clinician: I understand.

conversations.context: I was asked to see the patient for C. diff colitis.

dialogue.message: Are you fired for a right abdominal infection? Patient: Yes, they told me I could have C Diff?  Yes that's why we're going to evaluate you.

conversations.context: Nothing significant.

dialogue.message: Have you had a recent vaccination? Patient: I had an influenza vaccine last winter but I didn't have and recent vaccines.  Did you plan anything in the near future? Patient: I was going to have another influenza vaccine but I don't think I'm due for that for another three months.  Super.

conversations.context: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, altered mental status.

dialogue.message: How long has he been since you noticed behavior changes? Guest_family: A few days ago.  Did he complain about any pain? Guest_family: Yes, he was-  Was he? Guest_family: Sorry, my phone was on vibrates and I had to turn it off.  No problem. Guest_family: He pointed to his stomach and said it hurts.  Does he have any other symptoms? Guest_family: He told me he was feeling calm. I took his temperature the other night and he was running a fever of an O two.  Everything vomited with nausea? Guest_family: Yes, he vomited a few times.

conversations.context: The patient is now approximately week status post removal of Ex-Fix from the right knee with an MUA following open reduction internal fixation of right tibial plateau fracture.  The patient states that this pain is well controlled.  He has had no fevers, chills or night sweats.  He has had some mild drainage from his pin sites.  He just started doing range of motion type exercises for his right knee.  He has had no numbness or tingling.

dialogue.message: Very well, and just to remind you, you had a withdrawal of the Ex Fix from the right knee with a M U A following O R I F of a fracture of the right tibial plateau. Patient: Yes, it looks familiar. What is M U A?  This is manipulation under anesthesia. We folded the knee in order to break by force some scar tissue. Patient: Oh, wow.  Yes, it's great, eliminates a certain need for P T in fact. How do you do it today? Patient: Overall, my pain is under control.  You have an influenza like, or symptoms of infection? Patient: No, nothing like that.  So, no fever, or chills, or sweating during the night. Patient: Yes, nothing like that.  Super. I see you have no drainage of the pining sites, but it doesn't bother me too much. Pattor: Ok, good, no sweat.

conversations.context: The patient is a 5-year, 8-month-old male who presented to me direct from ED with distracted left lateral condyle fracture.  He underwent screw compression for the fracture in October 2007.  The fracture has subsequently healed and the patient presents for hardware removal.  The risks and benefits of surgery were discussed.  The risks of surgery include the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of extremity, failure of removal of hardware, failure to relieve pain or improved range of motion.  All questions were answered and the family agreed to the above plan.

dialogue.message: Hello. How do you do today? Guest_family: We are doing very well. The ED told us to come here. We are here to see if we could get things out in his leg.  I see. Did he have a fracture before? Guest_family: Yes, he did. Here is the report of the October surgery two thousand seven.  Great. Let me look. It seems that he had a lateral fracture of distracted condyl. He then underwent a screw compression to repair the fracture, correct? Guest_family: That's right.  Perfect. So now we have to remove the material that was used to repair the fracture, correct? Guest_family: Yes, that's correct. What are the risks of surgery?  The risks include the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, change of sensation and movement of the end, failure of removal of the material, inability to relieve pain or improvement of movement.

conversations.context: Mom brings patient in today because of sore throat starting last night.  Eyes have been very puffy.  He has taken some Benadryl when all of this congestion started but with a sudden onset just yesterday.  He has had low-grade fever and just felt very run down, appearing very tired.  He is still eating and drinking well, and his voice has been hoarse but no coughing.  No shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea or abdominal pain.

dialogue.message: I noticed that his eyes were really swollen before going to bed and that's where I gave him Benadryl. At that time, he also seemed nasal.  Sorry to hear that. Did he have a fever? Guest_family: When I took his temperature last night, it was an O.  And did you give him anything for the fever? Guest_family: I was worried to give him something on top of Benadryl.  I see. And how did he feel differently? Guest_family: It seems more loose than usual. Fortunately, he eats and drinks well.  Did he cough at all? Guest_family: No, but his voice was a sort of raspy.  Any shortness of breath? Guest_family: Hum no.  Why not episodes of vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach pain? Guest_family: No, I don't think so.

conversations.context: This is a 43-year-old black man with no apparent past medical history who presented to the emergency room with the chief complaint of weakness, malaise and dyspnea on exertion for approximately one month.  The patient also reports a 15-pound weight loss.  He denies fever, chills and sweats.  He denies cough and diarrhea.  He has mild anorexia.

dialogue.message: I am forty-three years old and this is the first time that I have had a major problem. It is only this month that I have felt weaker than usual. I am much tireder and short of breath every time I move.  Recent weight loss? Patient: Yes, I have lost about fifteen pounds in less than two or three months.  How is your appetite? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea? Patient: The appetite is good enough. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.  How is fever, chills, sweating, cough? Patient: No, ma'am.  And all chest pain with your breathlessness? Patient: No, ma'am.

conversations.context: Headache and pain in the neck and lower back.

dialogue.message: I had a headache all week with the neck and the pain of the lower back.  How would you describe the headache? Patient: Is it constant? Patient: He comes and goes for the most part.  How would you judge him on a scale of ten with ten being the worst? Patient: One seven or eight.  Do you have a headache now? Patient: No, not well this second.  Did you take - Patient: Nothing for pain?  Yes. Patient: I took a little Ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much.  Any other symptoms associated with headaches, such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision or sensitivity to light? Patient: No, not really.

conversations.context: Negative for rheumatic fever.  The patient has usual childhood illnesses.

dialogue.message: Do you have a history of rheumatic fever during your childhood? Patient: No.  A history of other usual childhood diseases? Patient: No.

conversations.context: CONSTITUTIONAL:  No history of fever, rigors, or chills. HEENT:  No history of cataract, blurring vision, or glaucoma.  RESPIRATORY:  Shortness of breath.  No pneumonia or valley fever. GASTROINTESTINAL:  No epigastric discomfort, hematemesis, or melena. UROLOGICAL:  No frequency or urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL:  No arthritis or muscle weakness. CNS:  No TIA.  No CVA.  No seizure disorder. ENDOCRINE:  Nonsignificant. HEMATOLOGICAL:  Nonsignificant.

dialogue.message: You have observed blood in your stools or in your vomiting? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: Okay, well. Have you noticed an increase in your frequency of urine or your emergency? Patient: No.  Do you feel muscle weakness or fatigue? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: None of the known history of arthritis? Patient: No. Patient: And no fever due to fungal infection or something, is it not? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: None of the history of pneumonia? Patient: No. Patient: And I am looking at your record, so no antecedents of stroke, C V A, or a convulsive disorder. Patient: That's right. Patient: No problem related to thyroid or hormone? Patient: No.  And you have no blood problems, that's correct. Patient: No problem with thyroid or hormone.

conversations.context: The patient has multiple medical problems, for which she is under the care of Dr. X.  She has a history of chronic obstructive lung disease and a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease.  There is a history of anemia and there is a history of sciatica, which has been caused by arthritis.  The patient has had skin cancers, which have been treated with local excision.

dialogue.message: So, what brings you here today? Patient: Well, I have a lot of medical problems and I see Doctor X for them, but I wanted a second opinion, so he sent me back here.  Yes, he's a good man! Don't worry, we'll take care of you. Patient: Thank you.  So, let me start by getting your medical history. Patient: Of course, I had skin cancer that was treated by the withdrawal of this part.  Ok. Patient: Other than that, I have an anaemia and an acid reflux problem. I also have a history of C O P D.  Very well. Patient: I also suffer from sciatica that was caused mainly by my arthritis.  I see.

conversations.context: Mr. Sample Patient returns to the Sample Clinic with the chief complaint of painful right heel.  The patient states that the heel has been painful for approximately two weeks, it is starts with the first step in the morning and gets worse with activity during the day.  The patient states that he is currently doing no treatment for it.  He states that most of his pain is along medial tubercle of the right calcaneus and extends to the medial arch.  The patient states that he has no change in the past medical history since his last visit and denies any fever, chills, vomiting, headache, chest, or shortness of breath.

dialogue.message: What is the problem today, sir? Patient: When is the pain the worst? Patient: Honestly, it starts with the first stage of the morning.  Does it get worse throughout the day? Patient: Yes, it gets worse all day with activities. Patient: What treatments have you had for that? Patient: Well, nothing to this day. Patient: Where is your heel pain? Patient: It's on the right heel, then it's on the lower part of the heel and inside the heel. Patient: Have you changed your medical history since your last visit? Patient: No, it's the same old as you. Patient: Do you have symptoms like flu? Patient: Like fever or chills? Patient: This, or vomiting or headache? Patient: No, it's the same old doctor as you.

conversations.context: The patient was an 8 pounds 13 ounces' term baby born 1 week early via a planned repeat C-section.  Mom denies any infections during pregnancy, except for thumb and toenail infections, treated with rubbing alcohol (mom denies any history of boils in the family).  GBS status was negative.  Mom smoked up to the last 5 months of the pregnancy.  Mom and dad both deny any sexually transmitted diseases or genital herpetic lesions.  Mom and baby were both discharged out of the hospital last 48 hours.  This patient has received no hospitalizations so far.

dialogue.message: I see that he has eight pounds and thirteen ounces, and that he was born by...? Guest_family: Yes, section C. Yes, he was never hospitalized. He was born a week earlier.  Okay, I would like to ask you a few questions about pregnancy and other history. Guest_family: Yes, of course go there.  Great, did you have infections during pregnancy like G B S or S T D? Guest_family: No, I didn't, I only had infections to the thumb and toes and we treated this with alcohol. We had boils in the family, so I'm not afraid of minor infections like this one.  Did you smoke during pregnancy? Guest_family: Yes, I did, but I stopped after five months.  Sir, did you have D's while she was pregnant? Guest_family_2: No, I wasn't diagnosed with anything.

conversations.context: Upper respiratory illness with apnea, possible pertussis.

dialogue.message: What brings her today? Guest_family: Oh, doctor. She didn't do well at all. Guest_family: I think she's getting worse.  I understand. I'm sorry to hear she doesn't feel well. Let me see what we can do for her today. Guest_family: I haven't taken her temperature since this morning. It was one hundred three degrees when she woke up.  What time did she wake up today? Guest_family: Um, about eight I think. She also suffers from apnea.  It looks like she has a superior respiratory infection. Guest_family: Will she get better?  Yes, she should feel better once we start treating the infection.

conversations.context: This is a 56-year-old female who comes in for a dietary consultation for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease and weight reduction.  The patient states that her husband has been diagnosed with high blood cholesterol as well.  She wants some support with some dietary recommendations to assist both of them in healthier eating.  The two of them live alone now, and she is used to cooking for large portions.  She is having a hard time adjusting to preparing food for the two of them.  She would like to do less food preparation, in fact.  She is starting a new job this week.

dialogue.message: Before you start, can I ask you how old you are? Patient: Hello, doctor. I am fifty-six years old, now.  Great, thank you. What is the problem today, madam? Patient: Well, I need some support for food recommendations for a healthy diet for my husband and me.  Why would that be, madam? Patient: Hum, I have a lot to do, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, acid reflux, and I just want to lose weight. My husband also has a high cholesterol level.  Tell me more about your eating habits, please. Patient: Well, we live alone now that our children are gone, but I'm used to cooking very large portions.  Do you have trouble doing food for only two people? Patient: Yes, that's a good way to say it.

conversations.context: Allergic rhinitis.  Otherwise healthy 2-year-old young lady.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: What do you think doctor, what does she have?  Well, I think she has hay fever. Otherwise, she looks like a good two-year-old girl. Guest_family: Hm, okay.

conversations.context: Fever.

dialogue.message: Guest_family: Doctor, can you check my baby?  Yes, it is. Guest_family: He has fever.

conversations.context: Diabetes type II uncontrolled.  Acute cystitis.

dialogue.message: You have an infection of the urinary tract. Patient: I knew it was an I U T. I have already had it, but nothing so painful and severe. I feel like I'm going to die!  Oh yes, it's because you have something called acute cystitis and its usually very painful and can cause serious complications. Patient: Well, is it because of my diabetes?  I'm afraid I don't have any better news for you, but your diabetes is out of control. It's way too high and you need to be really careful. Do you take your medication? Patient: Yes!  How to eat? Patient: Yes, sometimes I don't care about my diet.  Well, you have to monitor your diet, you can't just be careless. I'm going to change your treatment for diabetes. And let yourself take care of the antibiotic that should relieve you.

conversations.context: Last flu vaccine was given on 1999. Last pneumonia vaccine was given on 1996. Family Medical History: Father age 79, history of cerebrovascular accident (stroke) and hypertension. Mother history of CHF and emphysema that died at the age of 74. No brothers and sisters.

dialogue.message: Do you remember when your last influenza vaccine was? Patient: I don't remember what month, but it was in nineteen-nine.  Good, and you remember your last vaccine against pneumonia?
